description:
I'm a fan. This is a great place to grab lunch when you are limited on time because the food is ready to go.  They have both indoor and outdoor seating with heating. 

My co-worker and I came here twice in one week. The different lemonades they offer aren't overly sweet. One day we both ordered the poke bowls which were full of flavor. The other day I had the truffle mac and cheese, which was delicious, and my co-worker enjoyed his mozzarella sandwich. There are so many options available that you can order something different every day.
author: Sandra C.

description:
The location is great.
The customer service is minimal.
The food is not worth the cost.
The location is by a nice park but the customer service doesn't keep up with the class of people Lemonade attracts. I love Macncheese and when I saw the $12 price for the heavily promoted Mac-Tastic, I imagined it would at least be warm. Does room temperature cheese sound good to you? 

Let's not forget, the music being played doesn't really fit the area and the only caucasian person working was responsible for trash cleanup. What's up with that?

I had been wanting to try this place for a while. From the outside the place looks classy but was hesitant because the food sits out under heat lamps. Can't be too bad right? It is though.

I came in and no one said anything. I waited a few minutes and still no one acknowledged me or offered to help, or serve, or any kind of direction of where to start. I asked if "this is where I start?" I got my macncheese, small portions. Hopefully it's good for 12 bucks. I went to the cash register and the lady just looked down at her phone. I asked "do I pay here?" To which she said "yup" without looking up. Some service maybe.. At least appear to want to work?
I just came from Subway and they did the same thing and I walked out. They're also closing stores. Never coming back.
Total spent just for myself is 21 bucks with a 3 dollar tip, because I at least wanted to appear like you should get paid for standing there.
author: Robert G.

description:
2 stars because the seasonal vegetables were not bad. But I ordered lemonade through a group order today and was pretty disappointed. 

I ordered the salmon poke, seasonal vegetables, and the truffle Mac and cheese through a friend. Although the seasonal vegetables and salmon was not bad, the salmon was not what I ordered. I was looking forward to trying the poke. I can understand if the salmon poke was not available (not sure if it was or not), but wouldn't the next best option to give me was the ahi poke? Or maybe just give me a notification to get something else? The Mac and cheese noodles were also a bit too soft. My friends thought it was mash potatoes. However, the flavor on the Mac and cheese was pretty good. 

I did order my meal during dinner rush, so maybe the rush caused some confusion. Regardless, I'm not sure if I would order here again.
author: Alice L.

description:
Been eyeing this place for a long time and finally tried it! I got the spicy fin tuna poke bowl and loved it. 

Here's how it goes:you walk in and you see 3 stations, a cold bowl station, hot bowl station, and the drink station-slash-cashier. I got a poke, so obvs I went to the cold bowl. You make your selection, and you are asked if you want white or brown rice. While waiting for your bowl, you get a number, which you take the cashier. This number will let the cashier know what you ordered, and they hand you your bowl over there. They have a desert case there too, for last minute decisions.

My bowl was only $11.50 and the brownie is $4.50. I think the bowl is super cheap for what it is and I think the quality wasn't sacrificed at all. Would definitely come back!
author: Jessica F.

description:
Team lunches are always fun because you get to try something new in town. 

Did you ever go to Piccadilly as a kid? It was 400 meters of choices upon choices. Crush that down into 12 ft with nearly as many options but probably 40x fresher than what they were slingin' at the 'dilly back in the day. 

But things go a little slower in the South and to figure out what one might want during rush hour in SF when there are so many options, so little time, and such a short line...who knew lunch hour could be so overwhelming! 

So first piece of advice, check out the menu before you head in! Figure out what you're craving, and they'll most likely have it! I went with their spicy tuna poké bowl. It's a copious amount of rice but the fish and other toppings were fresh and hit the spot. 

The patio area is nice if you're looking to get out of the office. 

I think the folks at the register were very pleasant though it would've been helpful if the folks serving at the beginning of the line were trained to better navigate the dumbfounded customers trying to decide between all the things.
author: Morgan F.

description: very underwhelming and kind of expensive for the quality, keeping in mind that everything is pre-made. had way better experiences in LA at this chain.
author: Christina L.

description:
Like the name suggests, they serve lemonade, but they also have a lot of healthy lunch options such as poke bowls, salads, and sandwiches. I liked the cucumber mint lemonade (with less ice). The poke bowls have fresh fish, and you can never go wrong with a poke bowl. However, compared to all the other poke places in the city, this one is average. Even though their fish is good, their carbs are not made to perfection. The rice or soba noodles are usually too soggy and clumped up.

I wouldn't recommend sitting at outdoor patio if you have the choice because there are many pigeons who watch you while you're eating. They will congregate on the tables where people left their food and will eat off of the plates.

Poke bowls are always a good option for a healthy but still tasty lunch, so I like that they serve the right category of food in a convenient location.
author: Andrea T.

description:
Came here at 8pm and it was pretty empty. The options are overwhelming and I was pretty confused on how to order when I came. The staff isn't particularly helpful either. 

I gave up on trying to decide and just ordered the soba Thai breaker poke bowl. If you're giving a long name like the "soba thai breaker poke bowl", you better make it really damn good. Unfortunately, it was not as impressive as the name. They gave me sweet soy ginger and not enough salmon. The soba noodles were pretty meh too. Food was overall a 3/5. 

Im deducting another star because the place was filthy. All the tables were empty, but super dirty because none of the employees decided to clean any of them. And I don't mean like "there's a small spot that can be cleaned with a napkin" dirty. They were actually dirty. The trash cans were also overflowing.
author: Karanveer M.

description:
I work around the corner. I was craving  poke..
It was 8:00 on.. wow I am super glad  your team pretty much ignore me .  After a few min the counter lady kinda. Acknowledged me. She didn't walk over to me  or even turn around. I probably would have worked harder to get her attention but, I was in shock at how old the fish looked.

The edges were dry the middle wasn't pretty pink. The  marinated pole also not fresh .

You could tell salda hadn't been stirred in a while.
I walked down to the hot  foods.. same story.


I assuming the team members in uniform at the  Both had just gotten off because, they didn't see my existence.

I have been to other Lemonades.  Wow !! This one is def not a good example!
author: Jason P.

description:
First timer here.

I walked in, was mismerized and had sensory overload from all the selections.  I was straight up confused!  I didn't know what I wanted because everything looked so good.

After walking back and forth staring at the food like an idiot, I finally said I wanted 3 things to try.
:) Shaved brussels sprouts and dates - super yummy
:) Salmon avocado louie salad - felt heavy and needed to be on a piece of bread
:| Soba Noodles & Kimchee veggie - I could have done without this one because I think the kimchee was bitter

All this for $13 bucks.  Fresh and interesting in SF always runs this pricey, I guess.  Plus, if you want a lemonade, it will be more.  I also ended up with a refreshing watermelon juice drink, so, I lunch wuz ~$20 bucks.  Yea, kinda spensive, right?!!  RIGHT!

Probably won't stop me from coming back because they do have some interesting choices.  I'll come back when the timing is right :)
author: Jenny T.

description: I like the idea of Lemonade, except that the menu and ordering is a little overwhelming. The poke bowl I had was good, maybe had a little too much going on as far as the toppings go. The bowl itself was 80% rice, 15% toppings, and 5% fish. I'm not sure I'd seek out coming here, if I'm in the area again, it's an option I'd consider but not for poke. The sandwiches and salads seemed to be a lot more inspiring, so I'd probably go with that for next time.
author: Lisa I.

description: Great fresh food!  There was no chaos when I was there (as reported in other reviews).  I guess I just got lucky on the timing.
author: Linda M.

description:
Today's orders:
* Watermelon Rosemary
     * Best described as a very "mellow" taste
     * Rosemary taste was present for maybe half the 
        drink then it began to taste a bit like watered 
        down watermelon lemonade with no rosemary
* Cucumber Mint
     * A surprisingly strong (in a good way) cucumber 
        mint taste that was not overpowered by the 
        lemonade
     * Understandably one of their most popular.    
        flavors
     * Very refreshing
* Blood Orange
     * A sharp tangy taste that was not expected at 
        first but a taste that we quickly grew to enjoy
     * The group's fan favorite

Story time:
Even after having been in SF for the past few years I have never tried Lemonade. That all changed today as some of my friends from the East Bay wanted to end our SF adventure with a cold drink. After debating between a Slurpee, boba, or Lemonade (the struggles of living in the Bay) we decided to try something a majority of us have not had yet so we came here. Upon entering we were surprised by the variety of lemonade they had. Thankfully the girl that helped us was really kind, let us sample the flavors, told us their most popular choices, and even telling us her personal preference (I would give a shout out but the name on the receipt didn't seem to match the face of who helped us). I ended up sampling and really liking the drink she recommended (Blood Orange) and my friends chose their flavors of choice. She didn't add too much ice (which was great because it didn't water down our drinks) and the prices were not terrible for SF and the drink size. Ultimately we were all satisfied with the service and our drinks. 

Tl;dr
The girl who helped us today was nice, we sampled flavors, and we were happy with our drink decisions.
author: Dillon T.

description:
I ordered brussel sprouts with dates, broccoli, roasted squash and kimchi noodles that came with a side of bread. The roasted squash was my favorite! Other sides were pretty good too. Kimchi noodles- not so much though.
Boyfriend ordered truffle mac and cheese, mango chicken, and broccoli.
Quite enjoyed the food but I wish there were more hot vegetarian options available to mix and match.
Or maybe I got confused by the menu and didn't realize I can order separtes?
Surely coming back to try out some more things (hopefully something hot to go with the cold salads)
author: Dhanashree K.

description:
I came to Lemonade quite a few times in between meetings at a nearby hotel and was glad to have a (relatively) quick lunch stop. Highlights:
-Jerk chicken is surprisingly good...I really wasn't expecting much here but they proved me wrong.
-LOVE the peanut butter brittle cookie. If they sold these in stores, you'd have to roll me out of there because I'd eat them ALL.
-The orecchiette and tomato pasta is a nice vegetarian option.

The layout of the restaurant is not intuitive, and it's not abundantly clear what constitutes a "meal." Every day when I came in, the staff were explaining to someone (me, the first time) how many items they could get from the salad bar or the Land & Sea options or another area on the menu. All that said, Lemonade is also super duper affordable by SoMa standards so it almost felt like stealing to get such a large plate for $13. Oh, and try the lemonade but do know it has a lot of sugar!
author: Willie R.

description: For what they charge it's a total ripoff. You're paying $7.50 for a dish and they give you 1 scoop this is ridiculous. These people that work here are so stingy with their portions. The food tastes mediocre not the best. I don't see this place lasting very long. I hope other business will step in and make a change.
author: Curry S.

description:
3 stars. Like the concept of restaurant but it's not executed well. 

the hot food was lukewarm. The jerk chicken was spicy - I like the flavor in it. The southwest chili was decent but cold. 

It looks like the ingredients that they use are quite good - wished that they served hot dishes HOT rather than lukewarm.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Now that Bristol Farms is closed, Lemonade is the next closest thing for a quick lunch. The line is kind of a logistical nightmare, you can technically skip and go to different stations but the layout isn't accommodating of that and it feels cramped. The outdoor seating is nice though.

The food is healthy, bland, and unremarkable. I've had the poke and ahi tuna which are just kind of neutral tasting. I enjoyed the warm vegetables sides like the curried cauliflower dishes and the broccoli parmesan, though the texture can be inconsistently mushy to undercooked. Good for a quick bite, and better than most Metreon offerings save for Super Duper.
author: Truc N.

description:
We ordered from here at work one day through Caviar delivery and while everyone else's food was okay, my poke bowl was so off I couldn't eat it.  

I emailed the company a picture of what I received, gray mushy fish... and never heard back.  I'm writing this review after a few months since I still haven't heard back and hope this is not their average quality.
author: Meghan M.

description:
Story time : when I was younger, I used to see all over the internet those famous Lemonade cup with the cute curvy handwriting. I had always wanted to go there. Eventually, I stumbled upon one when I was in San Francisco two years ago but only got to eat there recently. Besides the lemonade itself, I knew nothing about the food. I checked the website and it looked delicious.

Unfortunately, when I got there, they didn't have the bowl I wanted so I tried something, with chicken and mango. And obviously, I got a classic lemonade. And what a bummer to get a regular cup with nothing on it. Still, it was pretty good. However, the food was a little bit too spicy for my taste and I got full pretty quickly (I had some leftovers).
I will definitely go back there and try someone else next time !
author: Karen R.

description:
Very clean, friendly staff, food was fresh. This is a good alternative to fast food. Many protein options and gluten free & vegan as well. 
Food was delicious & many options of lemonade
author: Toni T.

description:
As a vegan, I'm always excited to find vegan dishes in my neck of the woods. And they kindly label everything so I don't have to ask. I really do appreciate that because going vegan can be tough.

That being said, I ordered the arugula salad with strawberries, the cauliflower curry, the avocado tomato salad, and kale walnut medley. As a foursome, it's called the Farmers Market plate. Add a vegan and gluten free brownie and a blood orange drink and I'm happy. But price was a little steep. Maybe not for this area but damn all my money goes to being vegan. I paid $23 for lunch. Such an SF hippy.
author: Jessica D.

description:
I ate lunch at Lemonade today and I was shocked at how much variety they have. Most things are a la carte for you to build your own meal, and consist of cold and hot sides. Alternatively, they do have restaurant combos that you can order if you don't want to make your own.

I ordered the Turkey "El Tijuana" sandwich with a side of brussel sprouts. The sandwich was amazing and the reason for my higher rating. It has turkey breast, avocado, jicama slaw, jalapeños, and jalapeño aioli on a ciabatta roll. Definitely hit the spot! The brussel sprouts were not as good, they were super salty and soggy. I was expecting lightly dressed and crispy like other roasted brussel sprouts.
author: Lillian B.

description: Came here and was a bit shocked. I got the blueberry lemonade and the white truffle mac and cheese. Total was around $10. The lemonade was a bit watery and the white truffle mac and cheese was okay. Would only come back if totally necessary. Way too average.
author: Wesley K.

description: Stop here to grab a quick bite for breakfast. I was encouraged to get the lemon pastry as it was the real deal and specially made. I was excited to try it as I'm a big "lemon anything" fan. I wanted to love it but it just wasn't enjoyable. It did not taste fresh and may have been a couple days old.
author: Tracy H.

description:
Ultimate breakfast burrito was tasty. Ordered a coffee to go with it. But after I received my meal in a prompt manner, I  just noticed this flier on the left side of the counter that would've given me a free coffee w/ my order.
When I explained to the cashier, if I could get my money back for a free coffee he told me I needed to show him the flier first. 
What gives? The fliers weren't advertised where I could see it in the first place. I went to the right counter and they were placed on the left one where there wasn't a cashier present.
*I then went to another cashier about this and she said it's for the "next" purchase - and NOT "any" as stated in the flier.
author: Dale T.

description:
"Cafeteria Style, but hella bougie!" That's what I thought after my first time here at Lemonade. I've been to the Metreon plenty of times, but never had the chance to try Lemonade. I've definitely been missing out! 

Let's start at how awesome Lemonade's atmosphere, design, and location is. This Lemonade is located just outside the Metreon Mall, overseeing the Yerba Buena Park. There are inside seating, as well as outside seating by the park. The color scheme is bright and beautiful! The design of this place reminds of me of the southern home they have at the Food Network shows! I was waiting for Paula Dean to come out of the kitchen.

The food here is amazing! Fresh, light, and very delicious American Style food. Their menu is very reminiscent of the food you'd find at a picnic. The way you order is easy! Cafeteria style, grab a tray, pick out what you want. There's a Land & Sea option, Poke Bowl, Marketplace or go Ala Cart! All the dishes is laid out for you to see. Salads and pastas, sandwiches, fishes and chicken, and side orders. The end is the cash registers and on the back are selections of lemonade and slushes as drink options! 

Lemonade is moderately priced, about $10 and up for a full meal. When I was here I ordered the Market Place option, which includes 4 choices of different kinds of salad/pasta dishes. The Soba Vegetarian Noodles dish was definitely a winner! Their mash potatoes is really good as well! Though I did find the slushes to be a little too sour. 

As for the service, all the employees are personable, knowledgeable, and provided fast service!

Lemonade is definitely my new favorite place for lunch! With its great atmosphere, convenient location, quality food, and fast service, it's one of the best option for food around Downtown San Francisco! It's flawless just like Beyoncé's Lemonade HBO Special. All the belly's better get in formation!
author: Oliver B.

description:
Upon walking in during a busy Friday lunch service, I was overwhelmed with options and a little confused by the menu set up.

After a lot of back and forth (and pressure from the staff, trying to move the line along), I ended up ordering the Farmer's Market combination of 4 Marketplace Salads: Soba Noodle Salad; Brussels sprouts w/ dates; roasted cauliflower; turkey BLT panzanella salad.

The standout for me was the Soba Noodle Salad, which was everything I wanted it to be: crispy, rich with umami flavors, and refreshing.

The fresh house-made chips I had on the side were great, too.
author: Herbie H.

description:
Overall rating: A

Belated review! Nice, affordable counter service place for a relaxed lunch. You order, pay, and take your food when it's ready to the table of your choosing. They have actual metal utensils here in addition to the disposable stuff! They have a bathroom that requires a code from an employee. Their outdoor seating is overrun by pigeons so it's not pleasant. I saw people fighting off birds while eating! Nice park outside if you want to enjoy nature. Here's what my friend and I got:

-Backyard BBQ Brisket Bowl (Our signature BBQ Beef Brisket served with Butternut Squash, Charred Corn, Cilantro, and Queso Fresco, over Creamy Mashed Potatoes and topped with Sauteed Kale) $12.50: Great tender brisket. A bit on the salty side. Tell them to go easy on the sauce. Great filling and affordable bowl! A

-Spicy Fin Poke Bowl (Spicy Tuna Poke served with Ginger, Crispy Onions, Wakame Seaweed, and Furikake over Warm Seasoned Rice) $11.50: My friend had this and said it was very good. I personally didn't try it since I don't like fish. N/A

-Cold pressed blueberry mint lemonade, $3.50: If you're unsure what flavor lemonade you want they will kindly let you sample some! This flavor was perfectly balanced between sweet and sour. With it leaning a bit toward sour. Very refreshing on a hot day! A+


Only down side is they're part of an LA based chain with 28 locations as of now. I usually prefer to support local businesses instead of chains, but sometimes you just need quick, cheap food.
author: D D.

description:
TLDR - If you're bored of normal salads, Lemonade has more variety for the same price. Mix and match salads, veggies and proteins

I'm one of those people that really doesn't enjoy paying $15 for a salad. It sucks that being healthy has to be so expensive. Lemonade is a nice compromise - it still ends up being about $15 for a meal, but at least you can get mix it up and get a variety of salads, veggies and protein.

Marketplace salads a-la-carte are $3.25. A Farmer's Marketplace plate (4 marketplace salads) is $12.50, so you save $0.50, and you get a piece of crispy bread. Portion sizes are about 4 oz each, according to the guy behind the counter. For the price, it's a pretty healthy, filling and satisfying meal. 

* CURRIED CAULIFLOWER - 4.5/5
[golden raisin, almonds]
Tender cauliflower, good flavor.

* SHAVED BRUSSELS SPROUTS & DATES - 4.5/5
[parmesan, capers, sage balsamic]
I have a soft spot for brussels sprouts. I'm not a huge fan of cheese though so wasn't sure if I'd like this as much, but the parmesan was light and barely noticeable. I really liked the dates for sweetness.

* PINEAPPLE CHICKEN & GREEN BEANS - 4.5/5
[toasted coconut, jalapenos, jerk dressing]
Could't really taste the pineapple but I liked the flavor and spiciness. I'd recommend this one if you're looking for a marketplace salad with protein.

* BAJA NICOISE - 3/5
[olive oil poached albacore tuna, jalapeno, grilled onion, yukon potatoes, olives, lime]
Meh. If you want something filling, this one is a more potatoes than anything. Nothing special about taste. Tuna was just okay.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Lemonade initially gave off an upscale/bougie vibe, but then over time, it became only slightly above mediocre. The prices also seem to have gotten more expensive.

You can come here and eat hot foods (e.g. meats, soups) or cold foods (e.g. sandwiches, cold noodles, poke, salad). There is something to eat for everyone - probably what they are trying to market. I tend to always get the poke with avocado and oranges, and the brussel sprouts. The lemonade here is flavorful but a little too sweet for my liking. This place is also open late, which is convenient when I'm in the area to watch a movie but arrived after the food court closed. 

Service here is normal - at least you can sample any foods you'd like! I have come here multiple times for a quick bite to eat.
author: Connie L.

description:
I like Lemonade as a chain - the menu is healthy and tastes good.   But the food wasn't very good at this location.  They do have fast service (much appreciated during the lunch rush).

The mango chicken bowl had some dry, overcooked chicken.  Not appetizing.  The premade sandwich was soggy.  The salad (I chose quinoa and apple) was excellent, as it usually is at Lemonade.  I'd eat elsewhere in the financial district. . .
author: Kelsey H.

description:
Lemonade, crunchy ice. Actually don't crunch on ice - it is terrible for your teeth!

At Lemonade, I of course did NOT get lemonade. I decided on a peanut caramel cookie instead. The cookie had peanuts, pretzels, and not so much caramel (dang you employee who picked the non-caramelly looking cookie off the top). If it had more caramel, I would say get it - but make sure they don't jip you.

I got one of the main salads. It left me thinking...if only this salad had cheese. Lo and behold, it was actually supposed to include it. I got a very uneven amount of the items - so many grapes, so few almonds. Zero cheese. 

I also got one of the market options which was the new mexican roasted butternut squash. Besides the squash, it had corn AND here's the kicker corn nuts, for a nice crunch! It was a ranchy-like dressing so the whole thing was pretty creamy tasting and a bit too oily. The portion is pretty small.

Anyway, I see the allure here, especially for vegetarians as I enjoy having a little bit of everything, but don't be tricked into thinking this is healthy. Sometimes they go heavy on the sauces and oils. I guess that while I really like the concept with ample options and their creativity in mixing things together, I wish the execution was a little more consistent. Missing caramel, missing cheese, and a bit too much oil.
author: Libby J.

description:
Hot damn this place is expensive for what you're getting.

Ordered some sides to split with some friends. It worked fine for us but I wouldn't go here just on my own. Food isn't good enough to warrant the price. 

We got the ahi poke, truffle Mac and cheese, brussel sprouts, roasted cauliflower, and kale salad, with two lemonades... With a total of $32. Seriously?! Not worth it.

Not a lot of flavor. Everything was kind of bland... Except for the lemonades that all had wayyyyy too much sugar in them. 

Place was dirty and gross as well. Trash everywhere, pigeons on the left trays. 

Only good thing is that you can try the lemonade before buying.
author: Mandi W.

description:
Simple menu, easy to order, comfort food.  
Fresh salads, I had the cherry tomatoes and avocado salad and really enjoyed with my Italian sandwich.  The store was a little messy but not dirty.  The staff was friendly and my order came up fast and accurate.
author: David E.

description: I ordered the "Big Chill" which comes with a main and 2 sides. My main was the Salmon Avocado Louie Salad; so freakin' delicious. Snap Peas and Edamame, and Arugula and Kale. Everything tasted great. The breakfast was decent, but I'd stick to lunch.
author: Reginice C.

description:
Decor: cafeteria
Service: friendly
Food: bomb

Frisco is hella expensive. How do people live? No, really?

I can see this food getting repetitive on repeat visits, even with a plethora of choice. I wonder if they change up with les saisons? What's the deal with poké suddenly springing up everywhere? So many questions. No answers today.

I'm warming to chain restaurants on account of recent favourable forays. Lemonade is a new addition to this list. 

Poké here hit the spot. Their cauliflower situation is yum. I tasted near everything in three visits because the staff is obliging and insistent in a good way. Consequently I can recommend: the meatballs; the Thai situation; all the pokays; the Brussels braised to perfection; that syrupy spiced bar b q; the Other Chicken they called 'jerk' but should rename; that kalealmond admixture; the sugar and sin coconut thing. I am not a convert to runny looking macaroni pies. I come from good Caribbean stock and processed cheese is suspect in these times and pies. Proceed with delight and caution.
author: Hadiza A.

description:
Was in town for a work conference and needed to grab a quick dinner to-go. I ordered their spicy ahi tuna poke bowl and one of their seasonal salads.  The salad was good, fresh and the dressing had great flavor. The poke bowl had good flavor but some of the pieces of ahi were stringy. 

If you're headed to lemonade I would stick with the sandwiches and salads instead.
author: Melissa H.

description:
4 stars for the lemonade, but just 2 stars for the food. I've had various flavors of their lemonades/limeades, but just recently tried their food, and the food really did not impress.

My favorite drinks here are the Watermelon Rosemary Lemonade (forgot the exact name for this drink) and the Old Fashioned Lemonade. During this last visit, I opted for the combo for 1 hot sandwich, 1 side, and complimentary chips. The balsamic chicken sandwich I had would've been pretty tasty if the bread weren't so stale. It was tough biting into that sandwich. While the mashed potatoes were absolutely delicious, the curry cauliflower did not impress at all. The chips were also pretty stale as well. Portion size was also fairly small for the (nearly) $13 price tag.

Service was great. As this is a cafeteria-style establishment, we were greeted when we walked in, and were nicely guided through the process. They also bring out your food if you order a hot item, so do remember to grab your number! You can also skip the line and head to the register if plan to only order a drink. Hygiene, on the other hand, left much to be desired. There were too many flies laying around and sticky tables galore. The restroom was also sticky and stinky. Parking and traffic are difficult in the area, so definitely stick to public transportation if possible. All in all, I don't think I'd be stopping by for food again anytime soon, but I'll definitely be back for the lemonade!
author: Kristi T.

description:
This place is good for food that's already prepared, and ready to eat. I like the variety of options. There's cold and hot salads, meat options, and other hot dishes. I went with a cold butternut squash and corn salad, cold curry chicken salad, and warm truffle mac and cheese. It was a great combination and a good late lunch.

Don't forget to order a lemonade. The blood orange is wonderful.
author: Ariana R.

description:
When this location opened up, I was beyond ecstatic. I used to eat Lemonade almost every day back in LA when we had one on campus. Sunshine & fresh go very well together. 
Similar to other Lemonades, there are four different sections: 1) cold (market) dishes, 2) land & sea (like poached salmon, ahi tuna) 3) sandwiches, and 4) hot dishes like braised meats and mac n cheese (try the truffle)! It can get confusing as a newcomer, but remember, if you want the hot plates or sandwiches, you can skip the line of folks getting their market sides to the respective section. You can also try samples of everything, and they always make sure to ask if you have any allergies. 

Lemonade changes their menu periodically. They have seasonal specials, which are great, but I always find myself deferring back to my usuals. These are my favorite market sides:
- Curried cauliflower with almonds
- Pineapple chicken with green beans 
- Soba noodles 
- Roasted butternut squash (they have this crunchy corn nut-like things in here, that make it SO good)
- Avocado & cherry tomatoes (sometimes there are way too many cherry tomatoes left in the batch - I'm out)
- Orecchiette pasta & cherry tomatoes 

For hot dishes:
- Truffle mac n cheese (treat yoself!)
- Roasted brussel sprouts
- Roasted cauliflower (this is SUPER flavorful. And it's wonderfully crispy)
- Beef stroganoff (this location does not have it...)

For desserts:
- Their macarons are probably the largest size I've seen sold out there. They do a great job.

It can get overwhelming because of all the options, so make sure you grab a menu to scope out the prices or ask someone (everyone is friendly!) before you get surprised at the register. It can rack up as you pass through the line and see all the greatness.
author: Vickie Z.

description:
I had heard so much about Lemonade before visiting SF, so I was really looking forward to trying it! 

It was very busy when we arrived, but the staff were efficient and kept the line moving which was nice. The weather was beautiful the day we went and it was great to sit on the patio. 

I got their new "soba thai breaker poke bowl" and it was great! It just tasted super fresh and the flavours worked well together. The portion was huge and I thought it was a pretty good value. 

I also tried the watermelon lemonade and it was SO. REFRESHING. They had white truffle mac & cheese which I am dying to try, so I'll have to go back for that.
author: Jessica G.

description: This place has poppin' vibes. The light aesthetics, the layout of the restaurant, the colors, it's pretty friendly here. I got one of the the poke bowls, and as one of the people who has poke monthly, this wasn't the best. The portion was huge for a fair price of its size, but it lacks flavor and there was too much carbs to balance out the toppings of meat, ginger, etc. Also I'm thinking about how long the raw tuna has been sitting out. It wasn't cold enough and that definitely isn't healthy for anyone. Other than that, the workers are cute and can manage rush hours pretty well without being overwhelmed.
author: June P.

description:
The lemonade (the drink, not the restaurant) is 5 star.  Everything else, not so much.

Ordering the food is super confusing and it was so loud in there that we could not hear the staff person who was trying to explain it, so we just punted.

Portions are STINGY small, and the prices were high.  (4 meatballs for $8.50, no side, not even bread.)

When I finally decided I wanted the meatballs, I had to stand at the counter until the staff were done with their own personal conversation.  When they finally realized I was there, they seemed surprised and told me I was not the next in line.  Geez guys.  Wake up.

 Overall, go for a lemonade and eat someplace else.
author: Carol J.

description:
I have to start off by saying - I really really like the flavored lemonades here! Cucumber Mint? Watermelon Rosemary? Blood Orange?! I still haven't tried them all yet, but plan to in the very near future! 

The food is pretty delicious and super healthy with a wide range of veggie centric food items in their 'marketplace' section like curried cauliflower (with golden raisins and almonds), avocado and tomatoes (in a vinaigrette) and shaved brussel sprouts and dates (with parm cheese and balsam!) to name a few. They also have an assortment of other things like sandwiches, 'land and sea' (which includes chicken, fish and beef items), and hot dishes. This location has some specials too where you can order a combination of items for $11-$14. 

You can't really go wrong with your orders here, everything is pretty delicious and fresh. My go to's are the curry cauliflower (marketplace), curried apple and chicken (land and sea), turkey BLT with avocado (sandwiches) and of course a choice in lemonade! I would say though that there are a lot of items on the menu and when you're on line, it's a lot of food items to look through and choose. I've been here several times already and I still get confused when I try to choose combos or when I'm trying to decide how to best order my items so that I'm not completely overspending. 

Overall, it's a really solid place for food and I would stop by even just for some lemonade (which apparently you don't have to wait in line for - you can just order at the register). Outdoor and indoor seating is available and it's right by Yerba Buena gardens so on a nice day you can order and enjoy your meal on the grass while soaking up some vitamin D!
author: Deanna S.

description: I had such a bizarre experience here today. I went in with a hot bar item in mind and asked for a sample of the truffle mac & cheese as I was trying to make a decision as to what I would order. The one woman working behind the counter was already tied up with other customers, so she asked the cash register attendant to help me instead. I asked that individual for a sample, and she proceeded to grab a full-size to-go cup. I stated again that I wanted just a sample, but she started to fill the to-go cup as if I were making a full order. The original woman then yelled at her that I only wanted a sample, took the cup away that now had about half a scoop of macaroni in it, threw it away, and then proceeded to give me a sample of a literally two noodles as if I had done something wrong. It was so strange and aggressive that it just didn't make any sense. At that point, when your coworker has made a mistake, wouldn't you just stop her and have her give me whatever she had already put in the cup as a sample rather than throwing it away and giving me two measly noodles with attitude? It was all together a very odd interaction and I ended up just walking out without even trying the two noodles that she gave me...
author: Tay H.

description:
Wow. So after hearing all the buzz about this place from peeps in SoCal, I've been wanting to stop by and check out one of their locations ever since they've been popping up all over the Bay. I've been holding out waiting for the Berkeley location to open on 4th street but I haven't heard anything new happening there (you guys still opening there or nah? haha) so I finally found an opportunity go out of my way and see what I've been missing out on. 

I was coming from the gun control march in SF so after all the walking, I pretty much decided ahead I was going to end up just taking out which I kinda regretted as soon as I walked in: very bright cafeteria style decor, friendly atmosphere, very clean and spacious with lots of outdoor seating that I love. Everyone was very friendly. Very welcoming vibe that made me just want to sit down and enjoy my meal there but alas, I was on the move. I ordered:

Watermelon Rosemary - Didn't blow my mind but very refreshing drink and exactly what I needed to top off a very long day. Would try again (along with other flavors of course)

Citrus Poached Salmon Fillet - Melt in your mouth good. I was pleasantly surprised as I'm naturally skeptical of salmon in chain restaurants but this salmon was legit. 

White Truffle Mac n Cheese -  Must try! Very creamy, savory and delicious. Everyone I know that's been here raves about the mac n cheese and it definitely lived up the hype. 

Roasted Brocoli - Not as amazing as the other two sides but still solid and worth trying. 

All healthy sized portions and while this place definitely isn't cheap, for the quality and portions, I looked at my receipt ($22.50) not feeling too jipped. Only downside now is that I'm going to be really, really bummed if the Berkeley location never opens because I'm sure I'd be there all the time :). I'm definitely coming back in the mean time though.
author: Brianna B.

description:
I stopped by Lemonade for lunch a couple of days ago as I was passing through the area. Upon entering there seemed to be a long cafeteria style counter to the right with a long line in font so I dutifully queued up. I tried finding a menu board but could not identify one or at-least find one that explained what I could get. What struck me about this place was the silence. It was like everyone was here to attend a funeral. I guess this is what a super snobby place feels like. Most people in line seemed to be regulars who knew what they wanted. It looks like there are a bunch of different salads, sandwiches and entrees that you can choose from and they finally ring you up for what you've got.

After a quick look around I decided to get a sandwich and a side salad. I think I chose the kale salad ($5.50) and a salmon salad sandwich ($8.50) but I'm not 100% sure. The arrogant person behind the salad section rushed me through but forgot to give me any dressing for the salad which made it impossible to eat. The person who took the sandwich order was equally snooty. I'm not sure if they allow sandwiches to be customized at this funeral service so I stuck with their standard options (else I'd select a type of bread and ask for it to be toasted).

The sandwich was fine, but I would have liked it a lot more if it was toasted. The salad on the other had was in-edible without the dressing. I'm not sure if there is like a common station with dressing that I missed but I'm not that hardcore to be able to eat raw vegetables. Price-wise, Lemonade is definitely one of the more expensive places to eat in FiDi. I understand that it is targeted at a certain clientele, so all that I'll say is - Thank You but I'll pass.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
My chicken was raw and I asked to cook more and the person basically told no we can't!!!!! All my meat is at the plate! Would come back only for the Juice!!!!!! 
Blood orange is great! 
The cleaning sir is very polite! And the cashier as well!!!
author: Kika R.

description: I've always come only for a lemonade but today was the first time I ordered food. I got Turkey 'El Tijuana' and it was so good. The combo of turkey, jicama, queso fresco, avocado, jalapeño and the jalapeño aioli in a sandwich. Bomb! Today I tried the Blood Orange Lemonade so good as well.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Love this spot for poke bowls! The poke is really high quality and tastes amazing. Also for the price you can't beat it. It's the perfect portion for someone as big as me and I like how quick I can get in and out. Great lunch spot if you work nearby. Definitely check this place out.
author: Jordan S.

description:
I would say this place is marginal at best. In a city with so many options for delicious food, I'd suggest finding another place to eat. The food was way overpriced for what you actually get and to be honest, it was soggy and drenched is sauces. For a bowl and a drink my lunch was nearly $20. 

Really, save your money and go somewhere else.
author: Emily G.

description:
Lemonade's poke bowls came well-recommended from someone with really good taste in, um, tastes, so I gave the place several shots, but after my fourth date with Lemonade, I've decided that I just can't see us having a future together.

They made a good first impression, I'll admit. The location was close, the lines were short, and the serving size of the poke was respectable. It was also pretty yummy; solid mid-grade poke. The surprise stand-out was the shaved brussels sprouts and dates, which was quite yummy, even though it seemed like the server hadn't exactly packed the box tight. The price was a little higher than I usually pay for a lunch, but it seemed pretty worth it.

The second date didn't go as well; there was no rice ready so I tried branching out to noodles and it was pretty meh. To make matters worse, the box of brussels sprouts was visibly empty on one end, making me feel a little disgruntled. But, no one's perfect, and everyone has off days.

I went for the "spicy" fin poke bowl the third time around, and though there's nothing detectably spicy about it, it was the best of the bowls I'd had. I skipped the salad that time because I wasn't as hungry, and I felt like Lemonade had redeemed itself.

Finally I went back again, getting my favorite bowl and asked how much salad was in a serving. "About a scoop and a half," Lemonade's besties told me. I looked at the generously-sized scoops and thought, "Ah, it must have just been a mistake before." It was not, however; this was no heaping, generous scoop, it was a carefully-leveled scoop, plus about half of another carefully leveled scoop. When they handed me the box, a large portion of it was clearly empty.

"Why is it empty?" I asked.
Lemonade's besties looked embarrassed. "That's a two-serving box, so..."
I looked at the small box incredulously, and back to the besties. "Really?"
Again Lemonade's besties could only look apologetic, and I felt a little sorry for them, having to cover for their cheap friend like that. Not their fault.
At first I shrugged it off and started to just get the check, but then I thought to myself, "You know what? There's plenty of restaurants in the sea," and gave back the sad little box of salad.

The poke was still pretty good when I got back to the office, but it was a bit bitter to think that there'd never be more than that. I wondered what might have been, if Lemonade had not had such ludicrously small deli boxes.
author: Nathan P.

description:
My niece raved about this place so we decided to try on our visit to SF. Upon walking in it looks very promising however it was somewhat disappointing in the end. So so. 

I tried a chicken sandwich with a side salad, the blood orange lemonade, and the white truffle oil mac & cheese. My niece had the salmon with a side salad and a side of the roasted brussels sprouts. 

The line can get pretty long so we got lucky we were able to get in and find a table before our food came out. It was kind of cool that day so we didn't want to sit outside. On a nice day however, it would be a very nice place to sit and eat lunch. 

The lemonade was very good and yes it's very pricey but again you are in San Francisco and everything is pricey.
author: Juls B.

description:
Lemonade and Poke...  Hmmmmmm...

Passed this place a number of times during Dreamforce this week and just didn't get the connection.  Buutttttt... my curiosity got the best of me...  AGAIN... and I broke down and gave it a shot.  

Well you know what curiosity did to the cat...  

If you serve Poke on hot rice, you do realize that it actually cooks the fish, right?  Poke ruined.  I should have returned it as soon as I felt the heat radiating from the bottom of my bowl but I was already in line to pay and the one saving grace for Lemonade caught my eye.  Watermelon lemonade... Oh, hell YES!!!

P2P = ok, but the execution was a killer for me. 

They have other things to eat so I wouldn't say don't try them but if you want Poke consider yourself warned.
author: Robb M.

description:
Convenient, quick, and loaded with various options for all types of eaters and cravings. 

Came here with my boyfriend on the day of the Yerba Buena Gardens Festival. Not bad for a large crowd, service was quick and the food was perfect for eating on the grass to watch the live music performance. Although, we ate at the outdoor tables since I'm allergic to grass...

[The Restaurant] 
Decent sized and located on the corner of the Yerba Buena Gardens. There is both indoor and outdoor seating for your preference and it is very convenient to either stay and eat or to take and go. Upon walking in, they have laminated menus (in case there is a line - especially at lunch hour!) that way you have an idea of what they have available. 

[The Service] 
Quick and to the point. It's like going to a food court and ordering a panda express. You tell them what you want and how much of it. The kitchen/food serving area was very clean and the staff was friendly.

[The Food] 

-White Truffle Mac and Cheese is my FAVORITE. It is rich and creamy and the noodles aren't overly soggy. It's flavorful and the truffle isn't overbearing but adds a nice compliment to the cheese. One a la carte order was 4.95

-Butternut squash white corn Mexican Ranch salad was crisp and refreshing. A perfect addition to our mac. Some of the bigger pieces of squash seemed a bit underdone, but the flavor was really tasty. I LOVE CORN. One a la carte order was 3.25

-Blood orange lemonade is DELICIOUS! It was energizing, sweet, tart, and all the characteristics that you look for in a good lemonade. one drink was 3.50. 

Prices were pretty decent for the amount of food that we got. 

-Wish we got to try their giant macarons! Priced at 4.95 but there were other things around the area that we preferred. Definitely will come back to check out the other dishes.
author: Emily T.

description:
I was super impressed with this place! They have options for all diet-types, and very reasonable prices. My fiancé and I fell in love with their Mexican squash salad. Their side salads that are way more dense than regular salads, including soba noodles and such. AND it's only $2.95 each for a really good portion. We ended up getting a huge portion to go home with too. It was just too good. The flavor was just so rich, and not something I had ever had anywhere else. 
The only thing I wasn't super crazy about was the outside seating situation. I got pooped on by a pigeon... but I guess that can happen anywhere. Not the restaurant's fault, obviously.
Anyway, the selection and  quality is unbeatable. It's no wonder they have such long lines all the time! They move quick though.
author: Melanie P.

description:
I've been to Lemonade three times now. It's a good choice if you want something healthy and interesting beyond a standard salad. 

They have categories for their food - marketplace items (mostly different types of side salads), greens (larger, meal-size salads), proteins, hot meals, sandwiches, and desserts. You go down the line with your tray, asking the staff for what you want and then pay when you reach the end of the line. 

Since the last time I ate here, the staff have begun to serve the marketplace items in little dishes, making the servings a little smaller. Still, I feel like you get a decent amount for what you're paying.

I used to buy two marketplace items and one protein, but I find that the portions between their protein and marketplace dishes is too similar to warrant the price difference, especially since a lot of marketplace items have chicken or fish in them. I happen to enjoy marketplace items more anyways, so this time I got four marketplace items and a blood orange lemonade to share with a friend.

The actual marketplace items have interesting combinations, good seasoning, and are very colorful :) 

Of course, if you stop here, you HAVE to get their lemonade! I've tried their blood orange and their cucumber melon. The blood orange is, by far, my favorite, but it's definitely made for someone with a sweet tooth. If you like earthier, more refreshing tastes, then the cucumber melon is probably a better choice for you.

I would recommend stopping in on the weekends if you have that option, as the lines get pretty long during lunch on weekdays, since there are a lot of office buildings and a ton of workers come here on their lunch breaks.

Anyways, I know I'll be stopping by here again sometime soon!
author: Waverly R.

description: Was craving poke and came here! For 11.50 you get a bowl for almost 8 bucks it's a la carte. You can sample and select a mix between flavors. Very fresh and light. Absolutely adore it. During lunch time they have really long lines. Definitely a great poke place in the area. They also have plenty of other food from main entrees like rotisserie chicken to sandwiches like turkey BLT. Fresh, nice, and modern.
author: Amy Y.

description: I work here and so far just about all the food has been excellent. Come out and try. The Lemonade drinks are delicious if you love cold-press juices!!
author: Shauna R.

description:
I really want to love Lemonade with every fiber of my being, but there's just something about it that leaves a bad taste in my mouth (and ironically, it's not the food because the food is absolutely delicious!)

[Set up/Ambiance]: Cafeteria style restaurant, which is fine because it means you get your food pretty much instantly, but unfortunately I'm not the biggest fan of this set up. Going down the line, you're introduced to their cold sides first, but if you opt out in order to see what's good at the main courses/hot sides, the line is already so long that going back to see the cold sides is kind of awkward/weird. Maybe this is just my personal preference and anxieties kicking in, but I guess I'd rather just have it be an order and then sit down restaurant like Panera style instead of this weird line thing. 

However, the ambiance is adorable. The yellow, like a lemon, gives it a fresh vibe that I adore. Good amount of outdoor seating which is great if it's a nice day. Unfortunately, the indoor seating is really limited which makes it tough if the weather isn't as great.

[Food]: I ended up ordering the Poke and the roasted broccoli. I have to admit, they were both fantastic. However, they were both incredibly small portions. I paid $11 for two little cups of them which was disappointing, especially since I could get a big poke bowl for the same price. Ended up not even bothering with buying a lemonade because it'd run me another $4. Sucks because I know the lemonade here is some of the best! Side note, I noticed that they changed their Salmon Louie from an avocado half stuffed with salmon into a mixed salad which I think was a smart move. 

[Service]: Employees were kind and let me try both the Poke and the Salmon Louie first before solidifying an decision which I appreciated! That's another perk of being cafeteria style I suppose. 

All in all, I like Lemonade - I really do! But it ends at there. Maybe if their portions were slightly bigger, I could justify the price and my like would blossom into a love. But for now, I can't see myself running into Lemonade's arms as a regular customer.
author: Mars S.

description:
This is just for the lemonade I tried a few weeks ago.  I got the watermelon rosemary flavor and my sister got the green tea tangerine lemonade. Needless to say, this place's lemonade is either a hit-or-miss or a total hype. Mine was just bleh! This was the most expensive lemonade I ever paid for and it didn't even taste like it was made of real, fresh lemons. 

The watermelon in my drink tasted like it was overripe (in that about-to-go-bad kind of way) and instead of rosemary, I thought it tasted like cucumbers. My sister's lemonade tasted even worse lol. It was sour and needed some sugar, but the line was getting long so we didn't want to stay around and ask for some. 

The food looked and smelled good, but I don't know if I would choose to come back when they can't even get their lemonade right...
author: Myha D.

description:
Usually a huge fan of Lemonade. 
A SoCal chain now in NorCal. 

I always order the blood orange lemonade. Yum!
The watermelon radish with tuna is also a staple. 
Was so sad that the tuna was stringy. They left the silver skin on. I didn't finish it and dumped it. Didn't have time to go back and swap it out. Pretty sure they would have just done so.
I also had the poke and the fish was fresh but bland just oily. Needed more seasoning. No soy, no tangy umami. 
I ordered the tuna jalapeño salad as well. Good but the fish was very lean and dry. 

The highlight of my meal was the grasshopper pie in a jar. Delicious delicious ! The stars are for the dessert. Not ever going to this location again.
author: Sonya T.

description:
Not as good as the Beyoncé album, but still pretty good. I didn't realize this chain had gotten so popular until my most recent visit to SF where there are several locations. 

If you've never been, here's a quick summary. Lemonade is healthy, tasty, quick, and has several options to choose from for lunch. On any given day there's about 8-12 pretty clean salads, proteins, or sandwiches and almost as many lemonades at the register as well. 

It seems somewhat inexpensive, but after add ons and ordering a lemonade (which is almost impossible not to do at a place called Lemonade) you're sitting at somewhere near $20 for a lunch. Not the most cost efficient place to eat at everyday, but if you want a splurge it is a pretty nice treat. Enjoy!
author: Danny W.

description:
I recently heard about this place from a co-worker and was pleasantly surprised with the looks, not so much with the flavors...the place is bland. The prices are over priced and the portions are small. I will give them one thing, the Lemonade is fire! I loved the blood orange lemonade, they have many flavors and from what I hear they are all pretty good. 

If you are in the area I totally recommend you go in for a refresher but think twice about what you expect to taste, don't let your eyes fool ya' the stuff looks great but eh... 

A Plus: They're vegan friendly!
author: Karlos G.

description:
The place is called lemonade so the drink have to be good right?  Ordered the strawberry flavor. It was good but lack the punch to make it a lemonade. A decent amount of seating on the outside (with heated lamps) and a small seating area inside.  

The food partitions were a bit lacking (if they offer bigger containers) to my standards and I'm not a big guy. Got the mash potato and pulled pork. Both were very good and the right amount of flavor. The sauce from the pork makes a great gravy for the mash
author: Henry T.

description:
Place - clean and modern. Easy to acess, it is in the Metreon. Few
tables in inside and pretty many outside. There are heats outside and pretty warn at night. Menu is easy to read. 

Taste - many choice of market place, and others. Tastes are good but most many have cilantro. It is not strong buy, If u don't like it, check it. Amout of food is too small. 

Price - price of market place is not expersive but hot meal and others are pretty expensive and amout of food is little.

Service - pretty good. You can try sample.
author: Da Won L.

description:
At our colleagues' baby shower, we got Lemonade catered. When I first read the invite, I thought the hosts meant literal lemonade so I was shocked when the trays of gourmet sandwiches, salad, pasta, and Mac and cheese came. Platters of tucker and salmon came too. It was a feast to behold. 

I tried all the pastas, turkey, salmon, and Mac and cheese. Didn't have space on my plate to try the sandwiches unfortunately. I ate the Mac and cheese first and I tasted the savory truffle mixed in. The Mac and cheese wasn't too oily and was light, yet delicious. The salmon was also fantastic with light herbal seasoning on it. The other dishes tasted amazing too.
author: Nathan C.

description: A very clever restaurant idea - cafeteria style fast casual that allows you to choose from numerous pre-made platters, sandwiches, soups, salads, etc. Service was OK, restaurant was a bit dirty but it was 4 PM on a Saturday after what appeared to be a very busy day. We ordered two sandwiches and sides and waited a while for everything to get plated and brought out to us. Food was just OK - sandwich was a bit greasy. Didn't spring for any of the beverages.
author: Ben S.

description: Yum! Sadly they were out of a few items when we arrived (around 6:30pm). But the food here is good and seems like good quality.
author: Iris G.

description: I love lemonade! I've gone to this SF location a few times. Just like any other Lemonade, the line goes by fast. I ordered the new-ish mango chicken rice bowl. It was good and I loved the brussel sprouts. The lemonade is always good as well. I'll be back for more lunches!
author: Tilly D.

description:
Fast casual, definitely a spot I can see being popular for lunch. The location was bright and open. Plenty of options for whatever you're craving be it a healthy salad, heavy comfort food or sandwiches, or a bit of everything if that's what you're going for. 

I was just trying to grab something super quick so went for a sandwich and the sugar free mint lemonade which was really tasty. Not a place I would frequent but for the lunch crowd or when you're looking to grab something quick - which I was - it would definitely satisfy.

Highlight was the super cheery cashier who was chatty and complimentary to all the patrons while I was there.
author: Miranda R.

description:
When I lived in London, these kind of "salad" places  were quite common. Often with a Middle Eastern twist, where you would get your daily fiber-fix (think lentils and beans). And I'm pleased to say that Lemonade has now filled that gap. 

I've been here twice and both times I got the box where I could choose up to 4 different salads. I opted for the vegetarian options each time. This box is plenty to fill you up, but not leave you bloated and feeling uneasy for the rest of the afternoon. 

Overall, Lemonade has a bit of a chainy feel to it: everything is so organized, clean and - somewhat rigid. But, I guess with this location, they can't really be otherwise. Since I don't like the atmosphere here, I simply take my lunch to go and sit down at Yerba Buena Park.
author: Uli B.

description:
I had a very pleasant time here! The workers were beyond kind and helpful. They have recommendations and samples to make sure we liked something before we got it. I wish I could've tried everything there because it looked so good. This is a cafeteria style layout. You do not have to get anything from the front if you don't want to. I felt obligated to because I wasn't sure how it worked. The salads and noodles were the first thing you see.

The traditional mac n cheese and the truffle mac and cheese were delicious!! The traditional was so cheesy and melted in your mouth. You could definitely taste the truffle in the other one. I couldn't choose between the two and I didn't have to because they gave me half and half! This made my experience quite worth it.

The soba noodles were also pretty good, I mixed it with the tritip and potatoes. The tri tip and potatoes were good but some of the potatoes were still a little hard. 

There were many lemonade options as well. I could not choose between the blood orange and the cucumber mint. I wish I could've had both but I went with the recommendation of the cashier. Who was super kind and bubbly.

Overall I had a nice time there and would definitely go back! Great for quick bites and to go items.
author: Ada N.

description: Great spot for a hot sandwich, and the lemonade does the name of the place justice. I had the Herb Grilled Chicken sandwich and Blood Orange Lemonade - fantastic! If I had any criticism, it would be that the menu and concept takes a little while to read and understand. Price is great too!
author: Heather E.

description:
I was very skeptical at first of Lemonade, I know everyone thinks it is so trendy and good but I was the biggest fan of the cafeteria style service... but all of that was before I even stepped in the door. 

I have been twice now in the past couple weeks and it is very good! You can choose from an assortment of mixed salad options that only cost $2.95 each. Thy give you about a cup full! Which is very filling. I get full off of just two of the salads.  I would definitely recommend getting one of the salmon protein options if you are a little extra hungry.

One thing I was slightly disappointed by was the lemonade, the flavors were a bit weird and they all way too sweet, the lemonade seems slightly artificial, definitely not fresh squeezed. 

If you are looking for a quick healthy meal to grab on the go this is your place, and you don't regret anything after you eat it which is always a bonus!
author: Maddy H.

description:
I really wanted to love Lemonade. The food is displayed beautifully, there are so many options from salads to sandwiches to hot dishes, and who doesn't love drinking lemonade?

It's a great concept, but it's a rather hectic experience and the food quality doesn't really match the price. I've gone a few times and enjoyed the avocado and tomato salad, but the other salads were just okay. When you're in downtown SF at lunchtime and paying a premium, it should be delicious.

You can mix and match the salads with a "Land & Sea" option (chicken, salmon, ahi tuna, etc), a sandwich, or a hot dish, but it can be confusing when you can or cannot skip the line. It's worth a try, but not the first place I'd recommend.
author: Shira W.

description: If you want a fast and healthy meal, this is the place to go. I love the poke bowl and the Mac n cheese was also delicious. The prices are high for fast food, but I hope that it's because their ingredients are high quality. Sitting outside is really nice at this location. I'm surprised it doesn't have a higher rating!
author: Neekta H.

description: No menu. Confusing line. "Mango chicken" was covered in sugar sauce and had two actual pieces of mango. Sign says "with veggies." Which veggies? Way too much rice. But they have lots of options of lemonade!
author: Ian J.

description:
After seeing Lemonade come up quite a bit in my Yelp thread, I decided to come try it out myself. Walking in, I was a little confused as to how I was supposed to order. I grabbed a tray and noticed that each dish had a price sign attached to them. Basically you pay by each serving. 

I decided to order the butternut squash with red quinoa as I had no idea what other foods were available down the line. The server gave me a plate with the squash and quinoa as well as a number. When I got to the hot food section, I decided on the truffle Mac and cheese as well as the red miso short ribs. The mac and cheese as well the red miso short ribs came in a cup size container. As I reached the cashier, I was asked for my number and I ordered the pomegranate and tarragon lemonade. I mean, it is called Lemonade for a reason!

The butternut squash and red quinoa ($2.95) didn't wow me. It tasted like raw squash with cooked quinoa. Maybe that's what it was supposed to taste like but normally butternut squash has a bit more of a flavor profile.  

The red miso ribs ($7.95) had smaller pieces that could be pulled apart with just a fork but the pieces that are big were a bit on the dry end and there wasn't enough sauce for me to continually dip pieces in. The flavor was there but I'd request more sauce next time. 

The truffle mac and cheese ($4.50) didn't disappoint. If I ever want a cheesy snack, I'll come back and get this!

Lastly the pomegranate tarragon lemonade was a bit of a disappointment. It was too tart and the tarragon overtook the flavor of the lemonade. I drank about half of it before I decided I couldn't have more of the medicinal and tart taste. It wasn't sweet at all. Next time I'll ask for a sample first. 

As other reviewers have mentioned, you should be careful of costs. My meal costed $21 because everything just added up. You do get full off of portion sizes but if you don't want to have a $20 lunch, you may want to browse before you order. 

I know their lemonades are well known and I did enjoy the mac and cheese so I will be back again!
author: Olivia C.

description:
Overrated and confusing. Upscale cafeteria style food, which often ends up overpriced also.

The perk - they'll let you sample whatever you're interested in, so give it a go and be sure you love what you order. 

I've found that getting portions of individual things works better than choosing one of their plates, and take it to go.
author: Sarah G.

description:
My first Lemonade was on the USC campus -and I loved it. I needed to meet my daughters for a quick lunch in the city. They both work close by so recommended we meet here. Glad we did! 

Many choices and they are fresh and really good. Salads, soups, hot foods all available and made to your likings. Sort of high end cafeteria style, made to order with so many choices. Long line but it moves pretty quickly. Portions are good and you leave full but not weighed down.

They have a nice cookbook too!
author: Susan K.

description:
Generous portions by SF standards!

Ahi tuna and avocado poke: Not too much soy sauce, but ginger and green onion flavor is nice. SO SO SO SO OILY though, I wish it wasn't drenched in oil. I like the avocado chunks on this and at $6.95, the portion is a steal! Hard to judge the quality of the fish given the oil it's slathered in, but my guess is middle of the runway given that it's not bright bright red.

Brussel sprouts: Mmmm, not too oily, would get again. Tastes like good home cooked veggies.

Citrus poached salmon: Flaky, a tad on the dry side but still yummy. The sauce on this was light and refreshing, would pair well with a salad.

Thanksgiving greens: Pass if you're looking for an actual meal salad. Just a giant box of arugula plus red lettuce, although it was very very fresh and of the baby arugula variety! Yay!

Although it's definitely not up to typical restaurant standards in terms of presentation, it's made up for in size.
author: Nicole H.

description:
I've been to this Lemonade location during the weekdays, at lunch time and have experienced how hectic it can be. Lines get long but I really like their fresh food and the service was always great!

However, about 2 weekends ago a group of friends and I came here on a saturday and had a truly confusing experience. Apparently they were training a lot of new hires so almost everything you could imagine go wrong did go wrong. A different big group went before us and ordered, for some reason when it came time to pay they decided they didn't want the food and left. I don't know what happened but I do know that afterwards their employees took their anger out on us. 

Apparently the  previous group ordered a sandwich I had also ordered, so the employee tried to give it to me. I was fine with it because it was unopened and I don't want to waste perfectly good food, no one touched it so I said it was fine. The manager (who was also my cashier, and I'm only assuming is the manager because he was bossing people around) came behind the employee and reprimanded her in front of me. He told her that it was illegal and they cannot give food to another person then he told her to go "back into the kitchen" and she didn't say anything and walked back to the kitchen...it was really, really uncomfortable. 

They did mess up on our order and charges, one lady apologized to us and said they were training 6 new people so it was hectic. One friend paid for a meal but was only given a sandwich--we waited for TWENTY minutes and they never brought over his chips/side, when he went to ask they said it wasn't included...what...we literally all ordered the same thing except with different salads but his salad wasn't included?? Made 0 sense, they told us that the other 4 of us shouldn't have gotten salads. Um...no...this is literally on your menu. The worst part? My sandwich was made so poorly it fell apart on my lap when we finally sat down to eat. What a bummer.

Will I be back? Probably, it's convenient to my work place but I'll be hesitant for non-lunch time moments.
author: Cindy M.

description:
I like the variety of being able to choose from the selections provided and displayed. 

They have cold dishes, hot servings and sandwiches to be perusing through and decide. 

Their ahi tuna lacked soy sauce or more flavor.  I did like their Thai Curry meatballs.  They offer bits to try if you want to taste the many choices. 

There's a nice outdoor patio area. The idea of Lemonade is casual, picnic style and with an abundance of small dishes to enjoy while being able to lie down and be at ease.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
When news first broke about Lemonade's impending expansion into the Bay Area, it didn't make a huge blip on my radar since I didn't know much about them.  Some of my friends, on the other hand, were rather stoked to have another light and fresh option for lunch downtown.  And here I was, thinking they were all about lemonade, like Hot Dog on a Stick (minus the giant stomper thing they use to juice the lemons).

Since I wasn't all that familiar with Lemonade (obviously), I didn't really know what to expect the first time I came here.  Their set-up was a little confusing initially, but I actually liked how you can walk up directly to each station rather than work your way down a line cafeteria-style (though perhaps not during the lunch rush).  Especially since the two times I've been here, I was able to skip the cold selections and go straight to their sandwiches!

-- GANDOLFINI - Turkey, Chicken, Ham, Swiss, Pepperoncini, and Olives...$7.95
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lemonade-san-francisco-3?select=4nn8NdESKCDqal0NG6bpAQ)
I knew immediately I wanted to try this when I saw it.  The ingredients may not be super unique, but it looked so good!  There was a decent amount of all three meats, the cheese was uber gooey, andI liked the bitterness of the arugula.  Even the olives weren't too shabby.  I especially liked the bread though, which was soft and just lightly toasted.

-- AHI TUNA & AVOCADO POKE with Tangerines, Icicle Radish, and Sesame...$6.95
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lemonade-san-francisco-3?select=op5-6NIDedN0cRZQlJoFCA)
I figured it was going to be overpriced (and it was, based on the portion size), but I had been craving some poke pretty badly.  While it wasn't super flawed, I thought it was just okay. The tuna was pretty fresh, as were the rest of the ingredients, but I didn't care much for the sauce the used, which was fairly sharp/acidic.

-- BLOOD ORANGE LEMONADE...$3.50
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lemonade-san-francisco-3?select=Fn9_wmUJErYOj8c50jKhPw)
I was torn between this one and their regular lemonade, but the girl at the register mentioned this was her favorite.  After just a couple of sips, I could definitely see why!  While it's a little sweet, I liked the overall taste, as well as the bit of tartness from the blood orange.

-- GUAVA LIMEADE...$3.50
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lemonade-san-francisco-3?select=EnTAQ5TKfndHQlB3GoZU9Q)
I would've ordered the Blood Orange Lemonade again, but I had to try this one for the guava.  Unlike the lemonade, this was more sour than sweet, though I was fine with that (it's limeade, after all).  I do wish there was a bit more guava to it, but I'd definitely get this again!

-- TURKEY "EL TIJUANA" with Jicama Slaw, Queso Fresco, Avocado, and Jalapeno Aioli...$7.95
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lemonade-san-francisco-3?select=Gglr5xYcf9TDwVeC0W_N6A)
Not as tasty as the Gandolfini, but solid nonetheless.  The turkey, queso fresco, and avocado blended well together, the bread was just as good, and the jalapenos and aioli were great (the heat wasn't super intense).  The jicama slaw didn't do much for me (it didn't add a lot of flavor), but it did provide a nice, refreshing crunch.

-- WHITE TRUFFLE MAC & CHEESE...$4.50
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lemonade-san-francisco-3?select=SmsZULk0SzEnjqL5XFVmmw)
Despite how I wish the consistency of the sauce was gooier/cheesier, this was great!  The noodles were were perfectly tender and there was a good amount of truffle flavor in the dish.  Something like toasted breadcrumbs would be nice to add some texture, but it's a minor quibble.

While I can't say how this Lemonade compares to its brethren in LA, it does seem like the prices here are a shade higher based on the online menu's on their homepage.  However, even with that in mind, I'm more inclined to round up from THREE AND A HALF STARS since I haven't had any major problems with them.  I wouldn't make it a point of coming back to this one, but I'm sure I'll visit their West Portal and 9th Ave locations when they open, if only for their sandwiches and another refreshing lemonade/limeade!
author: Mike L.

description:
I'm always reminded of Beyonce when I think of Lemonade. Too bad unlike her album, this place left a sour taste in my mouth.

Tbh, we settled on Lemonade because the Super Duper Burger line was seemingly endless. Aside from the short line, eating at Lemonade was a poor decision. The restaurant was out of nearly half of their featured menu to the point where my boyfriend ended up settling for the truffle mac&cheese (his 4th choice). Some of you may argue that this isn't necessarily a bad thing, but when there aren't enough appealing entree options available forcing you to settle on a side, I beg to disagree. I hoped that since it was a Saturday evening, there would be an overflow of food options given that this is a bustling city and it was dinner time. I was wrong. To my dismay, I even had to settle for a less desired option myself. 

What went wrong? As for one of the reasons given to me by the shift supervisor, the wrong chicken was ordered for the mango chicken bowl that my boyfriend initially wanted. They only had enough from a prior batch to feed a small subset of people. This, I let slide but for 2 more entrees to be unavailable that evening, it was clear to me that mismanagement was a deep-seeded issue. The supervisor on duty also mentioned that employees called in sick, reducing their staffing. I know that the holidays are a busy time for everyone, but I think they could have anticipated for it. It showed in their lack of cleanliness and organization. I was appalled by the sight of dirty dishes left on tables and the messiness of the food serving areas. I think based on this alone, I was being generous when I gave them 2 stars. 

As far as the food goes, I couldn't even take more than 2 bites out of mine. I originally requested for the "original" poke bowl with ahi tuna, rice and seaweed. Unsurprisingly, they ran out of that, so I went for the spicy option. **HOT TIP** I would recommend sampling something first if you're unsure of the dish. I did just that and realized it wasn't that spicy so I decided to order the spicy poke bowl. I disliked it for several reasons: the rice was soggy, the coconut chips didn't complement the dish well imo, and the fish didn't taste fresh (how could it be when it was sitting out in the open all day behind a glass shield?). Never again will I order this dish. I could get fresher poke and better-tasting add-ons at a nearby poke joint for the price of this one ($11.50) or cheaper. My boyfriend first wanted the mango chicken bowl, which they didn't have. Then, he asked for 2 more meat entrees, which they ran out of as well. That's when he was left to order the truffle mac&cheese, which I'm glad he did because that was what I ended up eating in the end. I think the other redeeming quality of this meal was the blood orange lemonade-- not too sweet or sour. It was a pretty good balance. 

I guess I had high expectations after visiting the Palo Alto location, but they were hardly met at this one. As you can see, there was much left to be desired.
author: Brittany D.

description:
Pricey, but they have gluten free dishes clearly marked with a "GF", so it was worth it to me.
Hint: check out the menu online before going. I couldn't tell what was what while standing in line. I'm still not too sure what was in the brussel sprout salad I had. And I figured out how to order by listening to the guy in front of me.
BIG portions. Plenty of delicious salmon-avocado louie in my order.
author: L G.

description: I absolutely love their hibiscus blue pea tea!! very pretty and tastes perfect, not too sweet or too sour! this location in san francisco also has super friendly staff! i definitely recommend coming to this place when you're visiting the matreon entertainment center
author: Cherry H.

description: Great a la carte options for a light dinner one night for me.  I had the chicken and beans which were super yummy, and the anchovies and brussel sprouts which were delicious.
