Though I noticed later on that I had to drink a lot of water as I'm guessing there was a lot of salt in the dish.  You order at the counter and then pay for your food, so there's no table service though it was fine as I was meeting a group of people and we preferred to just grab our food so that we could carry on with our conversation without being interrupted.  Good location as well!
author: Carolyn L.

description: Went to lunch there as my wife and I were in town visiting family.  We needed to get a quick lunch and was hoping to find a place with fresh ingredients that was quick.  The food was pretty good and I would go back if I lived in the area, I just would not say the food was amazing.  I had the salmon and 2 salads.  The brussels sprout salad had way too many dates and the salmon seemed overcooked.  My wife had a brisket thing that looked good and we split a cucumber mint lemonade which was good.  Overall it was fresh ingredients, it was quick and easy.  The price was a little high but it's SF and the food was pretty good.  I would try it again next time I am in town
author: Jeff K.

description:
Their marketing got me to try this place in the Metreon (it worked!). There was usually a line during weekday lunch hours. Ordering was a bit confusing, I was drawn in by the combo set but the option wasn't obvious. Different entree/side options were presented along the line, it was difficult to pick right away since I didn't know what was ahead. Eventually I got salmon and a veggie side, however I wasn't aware the salmon was served cold :(

Overall, a place with pricy healthy options (~$15 for just two to three sides). The ordering process could be more straightforward and less stressful!
author: Jaclyn C.

description: More stars if I knew what I was getting myself into before ordering here. Used doordash for an online group order. Having never been or heard of this place, I ordered the plate where you choose 4 different salads. Portion size for dinner was tiny, probably could have eaten two plates. Will say that the options I choose were tasty- brussel sprouts with figs, tomato pesto pasta salad, spinach strawberry salad, and kale orange combo. My favorite was the brussels salad. I would have just gotten 4 portions of that instead. Probably better for lunch than dinner-or choose a meal that will actually fill you up. Real question is, do they actually sell lemonade here?
author: Kara N.

description:
Came here for lunch with a coworker. When you enter, there usually is line, as they serve the food cafeteria style. The options look good and enticing. But for the price overall of all the items, definitely not worth it. 

The portions were small and didn't taste that exciting. I was bummed, and so was my friend. 

I don't plan on coming back with all the other great options in the area. If I were you, save your wallet and take your lunch time stomach somewhere else.
author: Sonia A.

description:
the food and lemonade was overpriced. 

the food did not taste very good and tasted like the ingredients were processed and didn't taste very fresh.

the veggies in the mango bowl were microwaved to death and inundated with weird sauce.

the poke bowl was just okay - nothing special.

I would not recommend this place at all.  its very rare to have bad food in sf.
author: Ursinha G.

description:
Didn't know where to start when I walked in. They offer plenty of varieties - small plates, salads, sandwiches, hot dishes, lemonade, and ice cream macarons. I was kind of overwhelmed. Thankfully a server explained to me how this place is like a cafeteria and you just pick and choose what you want, get a number, and then pay. He even recommended his favorites. Don't forget a tray! You can ask for FREE samples!!

Ordered:
Soba noodles 
Watermelon radish ahi tuna 
Ahi tuna avocado poke 
Truffle Mac&cheese
Roasted Turkey BLT

The soba noodles were tasty! Loved the peanut & creamy sesame vinaigrette. The watermelon radish was okay. Not a huge fan of radishes I realized. They don't give you much ahi tuna with it. Truffle Mac & Cheese was delicious and creamy ! Good amount of truffle flavor and cheesiness! Definitely one of my favorites here! The ahi tuna avocado poke was okay, lacked flavor. Portion was very small for $7. Would rather get a poke bowl somewhere else. The roasted turkey BLT was good. Always down for some bacon! The sandwich had decent amount of meat. It can take them up to 15 minutes to make. 

The service is fairly quick. Great place for lunch ! Kinda pricey for their portions. Can easily spend $15+ per person. Not much seating available indoors. They do have seating outdoors with heating lamps. You can also get it to go and eat it on the benches nearby. 

Next time I'm here I'll try their blood orange lemonade.
author: Karen L.

description:
I love how many food options there were and how most of them were very healthy. I also loved that they gave you your side dish while you waited for your main course instead of making you wait for the whole meal by bringing it all to you at once. The lemonade is amazing too!! The workers were nice and let me sample the food & the lemonade, which was a plus.

Only downfall is that it was pretty cold. They left the front door open the entire time I was there.
author: Remy B.

description: Too pricey for the portions. Only reason I wouldn't come back here... it's a big rip off for what you get. Yeah I understand healthy and more organic meals are more... but I don't think it's reasonable here. Service was friendly and plenty of options though.
author: Hoku L.

description:
Shoutout the worker at this location that chased us down at the register RIGHT before paying, to charge us for a double order that we did not originally asked for. 

We ordered at the counter and ordered one serving of one of the dishes. We then noticed that they skimped on the serving and therefore I went back and asked one of the servers to get a little more. He was SUPER nice about it and helpful so we didn't think anything of it. 

Then, once we got to the register, another server who saw this ran to us to exclaim that our serving counted as a DOUBLE serving and that it costed more. Having said that, totally understandable that she was just doing her job but it was a little embarrassing to be called out about just as we were about to pay. I mean.. it was just a LITTLE but extra and also, why didn't the guy who originally served us more say anything? Defs thinks she may be taking her job a littttle too seriously.. 

After her mentioning this, we told her sorry and we just wanted one serving (sort of tried to make a point like really.. is it THAT big of a deal). She then rolled her eyes while letting us go. But really, was that all necessary? 

Sigh, and to add, lemonade is already overpriced so I mean having a LITTLE more than one serving doesn't really seem that bad? But 2 stars to shoutout the original guy that helped us nicely and gave us the extra.
author: Krystal O.

description:
I've heard a lot of good things about Lemonade and seen tons of pictures on social media. I was really excited to try this place when I came here for dinner with my friend a couple of days ago. I enjoyed the concept of this place as cafeteria style. You pick what you want, the workers scoop it for you, and you pay for each item you order.

Food - I ordered two items from the marketplace section and one item from land&sea section along with a drink. I felt the food was just alright. It didn't wow me and it was kind of bland. The portions were small and it was expensive for it's size. My favorite item i ordered was actually the drink. If they name their store Lemonade, they better have good lemonade! My lemonade was fresh, not overly sweet, and it doesnt give the dry after lemon taste in the end. 

** Edamame & snap peas
** Avocado & cheery tomatoes
** Ahi Tuna and Avocado Poke
**Watermelon rosemary lemonade

Service - The workers were nice and let you sample as many items as you want. Just be courteous and let the people in line after you go first if you want to sample a few more items.

Ambiance - It is located in Metreon and the main door is connected to the street. It is a great location and there are many seats inside and outside. If it is a nice day out, you can have a little picnic in Yerba Buena Gardens. 

Overall, it is probably just something I would try just once for their food, lemonade, for the pictures, and novelty. I spent nearly $20 for a small meal that kept me only just the right amount of full. If i do come back, i'll probably just go for the drink!
author: Allie Y.

description:
Lemonade is my go to healthy lunch spot and as a SoCal Girl, I am so glad they have them in SF! The salads are so tasty and yet so simple & basic that you can taste each ingredient and know that it's super fresh. I love their Salmon Louie salad and their Brussel Sprout & Date salad but really you can't go wrong. Their sandwiches are yummy if you need something super filling but the salads are what I gravitate to. You must try their Lemonade and you cannot leave without a macaron!
Reasonable prices for consistently delicious food. Can't go wrong!
author: Jess D.

description: Good variety, good lemonade, overpriced for what it is though. It is good that I feel like I can get anywhere else. Good but not worth the price.
author: Steven Y.

description:
Fresh and healthy!!!!! I was on the way to the airport when I saw this place. I was in a hurry so I stopped by to see what they had. I'm glad I came even though they were almost closing! Everything was on point! Food and customer service! Everyone was very very very friendly and place was clean. Thanks for having a cool patio with a heat lamp--kept me warm on a Monday night (7.16.18). Thumbs up to all the workers that worked that night. 

I also saw another lemonade at lax and everything went well too!
author: Jess M.

description:
So I gotta be honest and say that salad bars/healthy to-go spots are just not a thing yet here in Texas. Yes there's a few sprinkled throughout the Lone Star State but man it's not easy.

Lemonade is such a unique concept that you kinda cut the line accordingly to what you want to order. It's kinda tricky at first if it's your first visit but it's kinda like when you're at a buffet without the perks of a buffet. It first starts off with the bean salads and such, then actual salad bar, sandwiches, hot foods, desserts, and lastly cashiers and lemonade bar.

Prices are ideal and I must say that my salad was quite delicious and very happy to have added the coffee smoked tenderloin to my ceasar salad.

I'm an oldie but goodie type of fella and went for their classic lemonade, but man those flavors sounded awesome!

The to-go containers are very eco-friendly and the staff is SO FRIENDLY.

I secretly wish there was one here in SA but one can dream correct?
author: Tomas R.

description: I think this place is more interested in price gouging next door movie goers (AMC is next door) than maintaining a solid retention rate for returning customers. $19 for 4 (very small) sides and & a baby sized soup (perhaps sample size?).  I'll spend the $19 on an extra large popcorn and pretzel next time. (The food not horrible, but definitely not worth it. Just go to Whole Foods next time for a similar, probably less expensive, experience, next time).
author: Rob M.

description: This location is less than desirable. Management, keep a better up keep of your restaurant. You have got to address the pigeon problem with your outside tables. We saw this pushy pigeon with a missing toe manning the tables. Unsanitary much? #EwDavid You also got mosquitos inside by the entrance hall. Staff was friendly but when this stuff isn't addressed makes me regret tipping
author: Christian M.

description:
Food: what a variety they have here!

Ahi with citrus ponzu - yummy dish but slightly small in portion.
Quinoa with apples - this was a very refreshing dish 
Grasshopper pie - mint pie in a cup.  Oh so good.

Service: cafeteria style serving but the staff is ok here.

Ambiance: it's very laid back when you need a quick bite. 

Overall:  I'll be back.  A lot of options to choose from.  Just wish the portions were bigger.
author: Spencer Q.

description: I love Lemonade and stop by here often as a quick and easy way to get more veggies into my meal during lunchtime. Some of my favorite vegetables to get here are the Israeli cous cous, avocado and the broccoli with feta cheese. I LOVE the truffle mac and cheese and miso short rib as well.
author: Meghan M.

description:
Kind of leaning towards a 3, but then giving it a 4 since they are trying! Came here on Saturday for National Lemonade Day...FREE LEMONADE! 

This place was PACKED. Probably because its right by Yerba Buena Garden and people didn't want to walk too far to eat...

Food options are delicious like always. I love their mac n cheese, and definitely get their lemonade! I tried the new flavors: ginger green tea and honeydew basil. TBH, ginger green tea was nothing special but honeydew basil was delicious! Would definitely get it again. 

Service here is meh- line control not very good, and the place was so cramped. I don't think it would be possible to get a quick lunch, especially during the weekends. A wait of 20-30 minutes is required...

Still, love Lemonade and their overpriced stuff!
author: Hurjane V.

description:
This place has the freshest tasting food. I
ordered the cold poached salmon, soba noodles with kimchi, and snap peas with edamame. The salmon was so tender and good. The noodles had a few peanuts and a mild taste of sesame and ginger. The peas and edamame were crisp and had some radishes and carrots. I don't often order a drink with my meals but how could I pass up a drink at a place called lemonade?  There were so many variations but I settled on cucumber mint lemonade and it was fantastic. This is the first place I ate at on my San Francisco trip. I hope every place I go to on this trip is this good. Thank you!
author: Misc M.

description:
5 stars for the lemonade drink, 3 stars for food.

Lemonade is a cute cafeteria style restaurant, think 16 Candles but way more busy and very bright. I don't care for the food because it targets your typical kale eater, kombucha drinker and such and just flat out not good.

Definitely gonna be back for the drinks, the food not so much.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
This review is purely for the lemonade refreshment only

I was in the area and wanted to try something refreshing to drink.  Passed by Lemonade to check out what the hype was all about.

So what's good at Lemonade? Since the name implies Lemonade, I just had to try.

My order: blood orange lemonade

PROs:  the lemonade was not too sweet and had a nice blood orange flavor with a slightly tart aftertaste.  Was good!

Also saw that they sell other dishes which include salads and poke, which I have yet to try.  Looks like a cafeteria style pick as you choose kind of set up.

CONs:  It was a little confusing how to just order from the lemonades.  Seemed like you had to go through the tray line to finally get a lemonade.

Nonetheless will be back to try some of their other dishes.
author: Mary-Ann F.

description:
My friend recommended this place, so we stopped by for lunch on Saturday before our outing to the MOMA. 

The concept is perfect for a quick grab-and-go lunch - it's cafeteria style but not self service. They have a bunch of cold, hot, drink, dessert options all at fairly reasonable prices. What's annoying though is that there are so many options, and you don't really see them until you've made your way down the line. 

Portions are good sized; flavors are mediocre. I got two sides - the cous cous salad and curried cauliflower, and a BBQ roasted tri-tip sandwich. They were all flavorful and reasonably tasty for a $12 grab and go lunch. 

I would recommend this place if you're looking for a quick bite to eat or only want something small. Probably great for workday lunches.
author: Vivian N.

description:
Pro: a lot to select from

Con: if you ever order a sandwich, which we did, they may forget about the order. So as we were finishing our salad, we then got the sandwich 35 minutes later even when we reminded them 2 times about the sandwich.  There was no apology, no sorry, no nothing.

It's a very nice establishment - new and bright with plenty of seating, but the service makes me never want to come back.
author: Julie C.

description: Had the shaved brussel sprouts with dates, was mediocre. The BBQ and mash was equally as mediocre. The best thing was of course the lemonade. I certainly wouldn't go back for the food!
author: Jonathan H.

description: I want to like Lemonade more than I do.  The ordering process is really confusing.  There are a lot of salad options, which is nice for vegetarians, but I wish it was easier to order small orders of sides. They sell what is basically like 6 ounces of whatever side it is, which is a bit much if you want to eat a few of them. I'd love to be able to get a scoop of mashed potatoes without buying a whole cup of them.  The vegetarian chili is totally not a chili, it is a soup. It tastes a lot like a slightly spicy minestrone. The tomato mozzarella sandwich is delicious, but it would be better pressed like a panini.  I wish they had a panini press.
author: Niki M.

description:
Options on Options on OPTIOONNNSSS. 

Option One: Start at the cold sides: In terms of what is consistent - get the Kimchi Noodle, Brocolli, or orenchetti salad. In terms of what seems like they just tossed with no flavor (aka dont get this) - mushrooms and tomato salad. You can just get these a la carte (about 3 dollars a side) or do a combo with an entree. 

Option Two: Main Courses - Choose between a sandwich or a protein - both priced around $7-9, but sandwich is more bang for your buck. Chicken Sandwich is a safe choice, but the tuna and poke are also really deelish but small portions. They don't serve any red meat proteins unfortunately. Butt...

Option Three: Hot Dishes - Mac and Cheeses, Mashed Potatoes, and their flavorful beef stew and much more. I would suggest getting some mashies - their mac and cheese is kind of a hit or miss - even the truffle. 

Option Four: Desserts and Lemonade. Their macaroons aren't cheap, but they hit the Sweet spot-pistachio macaroon is very tasty if you like pistachios. In terms of lemonade, the water melon and blood orange are my faves. For 3 dollars, its actually really good. You cant mess up on Lemonade especially when that's name of your restaurant and now a Beyonce Album. They don't always have the same flavors, but it's always good to mix and match some! 

I love when chain restaurants move to SF like Fogo de Chao, Tender Greens, to name a few, but the Lemonade here just seems like an after thought compared to LA. This lemonade has the same food as any other Lemonade, but the biggest problem is the quality of service and food. I understand that being in the middle of downtown, you need to provide fast service, but holy crap, random serving sizes were just getting randomly pooped on my plate left and right - there just seemed like no consistency at all with serving sizes. I love the novelty of Lemonade, but hope they improve their quality over time.
author: Eric Joseph D.

description: Clean and great staff. Awesome vibe and great food. I also like the variety of food and flavors of lemonade and desert.
author: Faith B.

description:
Great concept, chaotic execution. Lemonade has the potential to be a solid, quick, healthy lunch option but the flow & staffing need some work. 

It's basically an assembly-line system, with cold items, proteins, and hot items. During the lunch rush, it's pretty tricky to navigate as people are zig zagging to different stations, trying to figure out what they want. The whole experience was really overwhelming, and the staff did not have the confidence to help us navigate... they seemed just as confused as we were. I'm sure this will improve over time. 

Food-wise: lots of healthy choices, similar to the Whole Foods deli section with a rainbow of prepared grain & veggie salads. There's also a sandwich section and protein section with meats. The salmon looked pretty delish. 

The lemonade selection is impressive with about 7-8 different flavors, and they can do an Arnold Palmer with any of their lemonades. The cookies looked good, but tasted super stale, like they'd been in the case for days. 

Overall, I will need to visit a couple times to figure out what's best & how it all works! Worth a try if you work in the neighborhood.
author: Nique F.

description:
Only got to tried the lemonade here. If you're only ordering drinks, you can just walk right up to the cash register and avoid the long food items line. I got the guava lemonade, and couldn't finish it because it was so SOUR. I saw another customer get the carrot ginger one so I asked for a sample, liked this one way more! It had a spicy kick to it. The cashier lets you sample as many flavors as you want so don't be shy to ask (like I was and got stuck with sour guava). 

Parking is terrible since it is in the center of downtown SF. But worth a visit if you're already in the area and need a pick me up!
author: Nancy C.

description:
What a rip off!!!! I know SF is an expensive city. But it's places like these that give you ZERO value!!! I ordered a fresh leafy salad for $5.50, saw a sign that said add a protein item for $6.95. I thought "ok salad + protein for $6.95 that's reasonable." NOPE!!! I misread it... it's $5.50 PLUS $6.95 totaling with tax $13.93 for a meager salad!?!?!? I could have gone around the corner to Trader Joe's and bought two premade salads for under $10 total and be full... but instead I ate my Lemonade salad along with my tears AND went to TJ's for a "second lunch". 

BANNED!!!!!!!
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Reminiscent of a gourmet grab-n-go, Lemonade seems like a cute place for brunch/lunch. It doesn't go easy on your wallet though -- a sandwich is $7.95 and getting it with one of those sides ($2.95) along with a lemonade (one size only) put me at $16 for lunch.

Remarks about the menu: 
Olive oil poached ahi tuna: Way too salty. Definitely not an enjoyable eat--would not recommend. 2/5 

Gandolfini: Not spectacular, but filling. It's your average sandwich. 3/5 

Pomegranate Tarragon Lemonade: Fresh and tasty! I wish it came unsweetened so sugar intake can be controlled. But I like the small hints of pulp and can see why this is its specialty. 4/5 

The great presentation of the menu hyped up expectations. Maybe I'll be back for a lemonade, but nothing more.
author: Julia Y.

description:
Ate at Lemonade yesterday for a little team lunch and I gotta say, I was pretty impressed. Conceptually it's a great idea and located in a great spot amidst all the SOMA office buildings. You're promptly greeted by a few employees who are handing out menus and keeping the flow of hangry lunch traffic going. The menu can be a little confusing at first but, if you're having trouble there are plenty of people around to help :) 

I opted for the two sides and one protein and my sides were pretty darn good. No complaints out of the asparagus tips & tomatoes, and watermelon radish, sesame seeds and seared ahi dishes. I ordered the poached salmon as my main portion but, I'd think there are probably better options there. It's pretty incredible that Lemonade is able to serve so many people and keep up with the quality and consistency. I mean, it was packed!  

If you don't feel like taking your food to go, there's a nice little outdoor patio with plenty of seating. SOMA is generally sunny, so stick around and don't rush back to the office :) All in all, it's a solid little lunch spot if you only have 30 min or so. Check it out.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
I first had Lemonade on a visit to LA, and fell in love with the concept. Salads, sandwiches, cold foods, hot foods (sides and meats) all mix-and-match to your taste, creating an incredible amount of choice. 

I was particularly impressed with their prepared foods, which doesn't just feature normal items like Mac and cheese, but also has items like miso marinated short ribs or shrimp Louie in half an avocado. It is for someone with adventurous taste, but also caters to those who want it a little close to home.

But here are the problems. Pricing aside (it can get hefty if you want to try a few things), they have no idea how to crowd control. People who only want salads will be blocked by others waiting on the cold and hot foods - even though they are supposed to be separate lines. There aren't anything indicating how you should line up. Further more, there are so many choices that people take forever deciding at the counter, after spending forever lining up. Each server has to ring up your items separately so that takes another forever.

Why not have menus up front, or giant TVs or chalkboards up top where people can see? Or a system where people pay a set price for the number of items they get and some extras for specially colored premium items? (Ok if they did this they better offer me some free meals at least)

Honestly though, I now have a love-hate relationship with the place. Most of my friends hate the spaghetti lines and aren't in love with the food. I still have fond memories of a few items I like, but it's not good enough for me to force others to go with me. Oh decisions.
author: Alice C.

description:
Food is nothing exciting...nothing to come back for. Not only that, the price doesn't meet the quality...at all. Close to $20 for a meal and lemonade for lunch. 
The only thing I would come back for is the lemonade, made from real fruits, sugar added to almost all but 1 type.
author: Saint M.

description: Normally love all other Lemonade locations but this one was a huge disappointment. Came in on 7/16 around 8pm. I had friends that were trying lemonade for the first time, including friends from abroad and they had such a bad experience. The workers were so rude and unwilling to help. The menu can be quite overwhelming and I remember my first time at the Palo Alto location I had somebody walk me through it, but instead one of the workers rushed us and seemed irritated the entire time while helping us. Serving sizes here were also a lot smaller than other locations I've been to. My mango chicken bowl was mainly just rice, when I've ordered it before from other places it was packed with veggies. As we were leaving, the same worker that was rude taking our orders just stared at us as we left, no good night or anything. They made us feel so uncomfortable the entire time, definitely never going to or recommending this location again. Head to Palo Alto instead y'all they're amazing!!
author: Prianka D.

description: All I wanted was ONE lemonade. They told me I had to wait in line with all the people who haven't ordered their food yet. If you can't serve a customer one lemonade, what's the point of even having the lemonade.
author: Kaitlyn E.

description:
The yellow decor is pretty and bright, but the metal tables outside are unstable and move too easily.  Not a great sit-down place to chat with friends or read, but at least they serve food till late.

Portions are surprisingly filling, but dishes are hit-or-miss.


---- $2.95 SALADS ----

BLT Pancetta:  2 stars
Cool idea and cherry tomatoes were fresh and delish, but the whole dish was way too salty.


---- $7.95 MAINS ----

Anaheim Green Chile Chicken:  4 stars
Tender and good. A lot of meat but still overpriced.


---- DESSERTS $6 ----

Grasshopper Mud Pie:  3 stars
Too creamy and bland.
author: Letitia L.

description:
3.5 STARS

I've gone to Lemonade twice since they opened. Once on opening day and again today. Both days have been busy, but the line moves quickly, so the wait isn't too bad. I've gotten my items for takeout both times, so I've never actually eaten here.

Thursday, May 5th around 1pm
*Baby Artisan & Gem Romaine with Garlic Croutons & Parmesan ($4.50 side)
*Herb Roasted Chicken with Mozzarella, Basil Pesto, & Arugula ($7.95)
*Soup: Broccoli ($4.50)

I had no idea what I wanted last week, so I just ordered a bunch of things. I liked the sandwich, but one side of the sandwich ended up mushy because the wetness of the filling soaked through the bread. It did have good flavor though. The salad was okay. Too much cheese for me and too many croutons. It overpowered the salad. I liked the soup. I wish there were pieces of broccoli in it though. It needed a little texture.

Thursday, May 12th around 1:45pm
*Marketplace 4 portion ($11.80): Spring Asparagus & Cherry Tomatoes with Tarragon Salsa; Roasted Broccoli with Ricotta Cheese & Champagne Vinaigrette; Orecchiette Pasta & Cherry Tomatoes with Perline Mozzarella & Chimichurri Vinaigrette; Lemongrass Chicken Slaw with Cabbage, Cashews, Rau Ram, & Szechuan Vinaigrette
*Soup: Corn Chowder ($4.50)

Today, I decided to try their marketplace dishes. My favorites were the chicken slaw and the broccoli. The slaw was tangy, savory and crunchy. I liked the combination of flavors. The broccoli was cooked nicely. I hate it when broccoli is overcooked and mushy. This still retained a nice bite. The asparagus was okay. For me, it was too soft and mushy as it didn't have any crunch. The pasta salad flavor was good, but I didn't like the pasta. It was too hard. I wish it were softer. The corn chowder was good, but a touch too sweet for me.

I can taste how good and fresh everything here is and I appreciate that. But with every dish, there was always something that felt off to me. Prices are a little steep, but they have a lot of employees here, so their customer service is really good. I've averaged a little under $20 on both visits. I do question how they portion out their marketplace items as I saw someone get the same sized container as me and they only got three marketplace items. Looked like the same amount of food, but I paid extra for more variety?

I'm sure I'll be back as I want try more dishes from their hot section. That truffle mac n cheese looks amazing!
author: Elena N.

description:
Gurrrl, this ain't got nuthin' to do with Queen Bey's vidja album. No, Lemonade is a popular SoCal chain that has ended up here in Yerba Buena in the wake of the massive La Boulange sell-off. This location was more prominent in my personal view since I live close by, so I had been particularly curious about this operation. I had never heard of Lemoande until Jamie W. and i were strolling down Venice Blvd. down south last summer and noticed how popular it was with the suntanned anorexic crowd. We didn't try it since I figured they'd make us get on a scale to see if we qualified as customers, but up here, we were feeling mighty peckish after our self-paced tour of the newly expanded SFMOMA.

There's quite a spread when you queue up, and several decisions to be tackled in quick order. I don't know about you, but I require a bit of menu study time before I dive in, especially with the eager staff ready to scoop anything in front of them. Scanning in a flash, I decided on a serving of the Roasted Broccoli with Ricotta Cheese and Champagne Vinaigrette and then switched gears with another plate with a $7.95 Butter Lettuce Salad topped with a generous portion of Ahi Tuna for an extra $6.95 (photo: http://bit.ly/1R3c7D6). Thinking the broccoli looked lonely on the other plate, I ordered the $4.50 White Truffle Mac 'N Cheese (photo: http://bit.ly/1Nvf1Gk).

Jamie was far more mindful of portion control and went for the $4.50 Grilled Cheese Sandwich with Aged Cheddar accompanied by a $2.95 side of Lima Beans with Strawberries, Smoked Gouda and Red Wine Oregano Vinaigrette (photo: http://bit.ly/1OudL6j). It was like a school lunch for the well-heeled Seacliff set. I tried their $3.50 homebrew version of Diet Coke and have concluded I should probably stick with their namesake beverage (photo: http://bit.ly/1VY3Icb). Finding an empty table outside was not challenging on a rainy Saturday morning, but we saw how much it crowds with the hipsterati on a Friday evening. There's way too many cafeteria-style choices not to come back to Lemonade, and El Lay roots aside, we welcome their presence.

FOOD - 4 stars...good quality cafeteria fare for reasonable prices as long as you don't go overboard
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...spruced up to LA-style though still a bit crowded in there
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...they're trying
TOTAL - 4 stars...El Lay comes to SF and it wasn't Armegeddon
author: Ed U.

description: Three and a half stars. It was good but totally overrated. Blood orange lemonade was really yummy.
author: Tee D.

description: First time here walked by several times it's set up like a buffet style but it's not clear how to order I finally decided on a Chill plate - 2 side salad and a cold protein delicious pineapple chicken with green beans had a little bite with red peppers the salmon avocado Louie salad OMG the flavors of dill celery lime avocado with the salmon just melt in your mouth !!!! It's a little pricey for lunch however I was not disappointed
author: Dawn P.

description:
LEMONADE IS FINALLY HERE!!!

Like so many others, I've been dreaming for the day that Lemonade makes its way up to NorCal. The dream gets even better because we will be blessed with not one, but SIX Bay Area locations total. 

It does get a bit overwhelming here, especially if it's your first time. There's a plethora of options: marketplace, land & sea, salad & sandwiches, hot dishes, dessert and of course lemonade, but you only need to know one thing: WATERMELON RADISH AND SEARED AHI TUNA from the marketplace. My #1! Oh, and the cucumber mint lemonade is a must too!

My eyes are always bigger than my stomach here, but I'm not complaining.
author: Laverne N.

description: If you want to have an orgasm, than I suggest eating at lemonade, furthermore you may want to try the turkey club and the pink lemonade, but don't limit yourself to my amazing suggestions because everything at lemonade will rock your body in the most fantastic of ways.
author: Joe P.

description:
Like a bougie cafeteria with tons of pre-made options, hot and cold, really streamling the time from entering the door to getting food in your mouth.  It reminds me of the prepared food counters at Whole Foods.  Everything looks so pretty, sounds fancy, is a tad pricey but tastes kinda mediocre.  For about $25 (after tax and health surcharge) I got two fish items, one side and a drink.  I don't mind dropping some cash for a nice lunch, but I feel like there are better places to spend that money in the SoMa/FiDi area.

Ahi Tuna Poke: Poke seems to be the hottest trending it food in San Francisco now, so there is some stiff competition.  The avocado made the poke more pasty than juicy.  It also offset the kick you get from ingredients such as garlic.  Overall, it tasted a bit too mild for me.  The tuna chunks were large, however, they were a little tougher than I've had elsewhere.

Avocado Salmon Louie: Very cool presentation.  Salmon mixed with all sorts of flavoring and presented in half of an avocado.  I really liked the dill; always a classic salmon pairing.  It was fun to eat, having to dig into the avocado after getting some salmon on your fork.  Probably my favorite of the items I got.

Truffle Mac 'n Cheese: Biggest flaw was that the noodles were quite soggy instead of al dente, making a huge texture faux pas.  They were very heavy on the white peppercorn and pretty light on the truffle.  There was ample cheese sauce though.  Would have been nice if they had some crusty gratinéed cheese or breadcrumbs to add a crunchy texture.

Guava Limeade: I'm a huge guava fan, so had to get this one.  It was definitely stronger on the lime side than the guava side.  And more tart than sweet.  It'd probably taste amazing with some vodka; too bad that's not on the menu.
author: Adam B.

description:
Love their watermelon rosemary lemonade.

I usually get their truffle mac and cheese and roasted brussel sprouts. Not a cheap place for a meal but they have a good variety of food options. A lemonade + a small of any kind (like mac and cheese) will set up back close to $10. That's SF for you. *cry*  Better drink all that lemonade!
author: Cicely T.

description:
Lemonade has finally opened in San Francisco. This place was originally from LA. They opened in the perfect location where the Metreon is. 

I came here for lunch with my boyfriend and there was a pretty good line. You get in a line and grab a tray and basically you pick what you want. The food and concept kind of reminds of Whole Foods. They split it in sections, you have your Market Place, Leafy Greens, Land of the Sea and Hot Dishes.  The Marketplace changes throughout the day, I wanted to get the poki, but they didn't have it during that time, but maybe later in the day. So it's kind of luck of what you end up with, you'll never know. 

We ordered:
Israeli Couscous: OK, it's definitely healthy, I felt it needed more flavor
Watermelon Radish & Seared Ahi Tuna: Pretty good, loved the radishes! 
Avocado Salmon Louie: Loved it! The salmon was so creamy. Great combo
Mac and Cheese: Pass, nothing special
Chicken Chili: Pretty good, not too salty 
Brussel Sprouts: YUM! Recommend! Flavorful
Braised Meats: OK, a little too sweet

Overall, I like this place! I think its a great place to eat when you are trying to stay on the low crab and healthy side. I look forward coming back here again!
author: Natalie L.

description:
I'm a fan for Lemonade but for first timers - it does gets a little confusing. It's a cafeteria style line on getting your food. The quality of food is on point and its definitely fresh. 

To beat the crazy line, I would suggest to come around 1PMish. I barely had to wait in line ~ less than 5 mins max. Once you are finished ordering, you will get a number and pay at the cash register. Be careful on what you order cause it can be pricey depending on you get. 

You have the option to select from:

- The Market Place (able to select up to 6 portions $2.75-12.50) 
- Leafy Greens salad (full $7.95/side $4.50) 
- Land & Sea: chicken, beef & fish ($6.95)
- Sandwiches ($7.95)

Combinations: 
- Marketplace + Land & Sea ($12.75)
 - Sandwich + side of Leafy Greens ($11.95)
- Leafy Greens (full) + Land & Sea ($14.75)

HOT DISHES
- braised, roasted, & rotisserie meats ($7.95-10.50)
- hot veggies, chilis, mac n cheeses, & soups  ( $4.50-5.50)
author: Jenn L.

description:
Lemonade is like that guy you're dating... you keep going back. But you don't know why. Every time you leave dissatisfied, wondering why you keep answering his holla.

I want to like Lemonade. It has all the desirable qualities in my checklist.

Variety of hot and cold foods. Check
Mix and match a la carte items. Check
Healthy food, but if you want a side of something naughty, it's there. Check
Cute name and decor. Check

But every time you go it takes forever to get through the line. And it's a frustrating line too. You feel the inefficiency in the air. As a fixer-type (some duragatorily may call "A-type"), I want to reach behind the counter and shake every one and yell "come on people! Get it together! There must be a better way!"

Usually I get three salads. This is my trick to eating healthy- variety. But every single time, I'll only like one out of the three salads I get. Every time!

It seems that all the salads are pickled. It's like they dunk all of their salads in a vat of vinegar. 

There are some things I like. But I want to like it more. I should like it more!

I probably will continue to see Lemonade. I can't seem to resist it's shiny windows and long lines.

*i realize my associating the eating establishment, Lemonade to problems with men is very a la Beyoncé. But to be fair, I'm more of a Madonna-era gal.
author: Bonnie H.

description:
Such a cute place. Love the yellow. Seating inside and out. The cashier that helped us was friendly. 

Review only for the LEMONADE. I got to try almost all the flavors they had last weekend. My favorites are **Blood Orange and **Guava. If you like tart go with Guava and a little sweet but not too sweet Blood Orange will be perfect. Great new addition to the area.
author: Sandy B.

description: Lemonade is always great and I wrote a review already of the food when I visited Walnut Creek. I'll just make this review short and sweet. We ate outdoors and a pigeon happened to perch itself right above us and do it's business .. splat! Landed in the middle of our table and it splashed into my truffle mac and cheese and my friend's albacore salad. The manager and staff here were really nice about it and replaced our dishes. Thank you so much! Five stars for the food as always and for the amazing service. If I could rate the pigeons of this city though, they'd get a big fat zero! Lol.
author: Shar M.

description:
As much as I want to believe in the hype of the newest branch of the LA healthy casual food chain, I can't. It's just okay to me. 

I will say that for a business operating on opening day, the line kept moving quickly and the flow of things were much smoother than other places that open their doors to the public on the first day. However, it was still quite a hectic time trying to navigate through the different booths for food. From what I understand, you start off in the "marketplace" where you choose your vegan/vegetarian foods, and as you make your way up the line, you can get "Land and Sea" foods (meat and seafood), sandwiches, hot dishes (rice, mac n cheese, rotisserie meats, chili, etc), and dessert. When you arrive at the counter, that's where you can opt to get your lemonade drink(s). 

On opening day, I opted for 3 dishes and one of their lemonades: 

Soba Noodles & Kimchi Vegetables - Soba noodles were very cold and refreshing, and had a good texture to them. There was a nice twist to the kimchi vegetables, as they were not red nor particularly spicy. I guess that's just to please the palette of the average person who has yet to be graced by the flavor of the red kimchi the Koreans are known for. Anyway, nice dish! 

Lemongrass Chicken Slaw - I didn't like this one too much, mainly because the "Szechuan vinaigrette"...didn't taste like Szechuan cuisine (i.e. not spicy). It also did not have a particular "lemongrass" taste to it, which was disappointing. 

Seared Ahi Tuna - Tuna was fresh, had no smell to it, and the crushed orange ginger ponzu dipping sauce is a surprisingly nice complement to it. 

Blood orange lemonade - If you don't like tangy aftertastes, go for this one. However, it kind of walks the line between "too sweet" and "just right". I have a feeling the other lemonades will be the same. 

Anyway, it's worth a try! I'm definitely coming back, but like most people reviewing this place, I also won't come back too often. My order came out to around $22...
author: Viet N.

description:
I know lemonade from LAX--it's my go to spot at the airport for healthier offerings. Until yesterday, I had never actually tried the lemonade but that was my favorite thing by far!

They have sides (salads, noodles, pasta, etc.), proteins (chicken, shrimp, steak, tuna) and a hot bar (Mac n cheese, braised meat, soup, etc.). They also have cookies/sweets and lots of options for lemonade. 

They offer samples here which I thought was really nice. It's pricey so it's nice to try something before committing. PSA: DON'T ABUSE THIS PRIVILEGE! We were behind a group of girls who had 4-5 samples each and clearly were taking advantage by grazing. Let's keep it classy folks. Also, they just held up the line which was just kind of rude.

They have multiple kinds of lemonade and we ended up getting the apple coconut lemonade and the guava limeade. Both were delicious! Not too sweet at all and really fresh/flavorful.

Food was tasty--we got the soba noodles and shrimp with chimichurri sauce. Nothing out of this world but it's great as a "fast" food option in this part of town.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
I knew this place from the Venice location in Socal and was glad I ran into it here in SF! Being San Francisco, there is a huge line out the door at lunch, so not the quickest lunch but still worth it. You really can't go wrong here but my ultimate favorite is the Red Miso braise and the roasted cauliflower, and the white mac n' cheese (and I'm not even that into mac n' cheese) and the israeli couscous is good too. The point being, its hard to go wrong here and most of the choices are solid. 

I would prefer if some of the protein choices were heated (like the roasted chicken) but in understand the salad bar concept they are going for. They are usually more than happy to give you a sample of whatever it is you are considering before you commit. 

Last but not least is the actual lemonade.. I believe they have rotating flavors.. but if they have blood orange when you are there, thats the winner. That, and that Red Miso. Those two alone will keep me coming back. The sandwiches look great but I have not yet had a chance to try them. 

Protip: They let us do half white mac n cheese and half roasted cauliflower. Definitely recommend doing that. You're welcome.
author: Thielson D.

description:
I walk past the construction every weekend and was surprised that it was all ready this week! Just last week it was still boarded up and in progress!

I walked in from the back door and was really confused as to where to start. I kinda stood in the middle of the room until I found some menus on the bussing island/table. I saw the cash register and kinda stood in that area until I noticed an employee passing out menus by the front entrance. Ohhhh there's a front entrance! How do I not notice that...

Then I also noticed the line for the food, so I quickly joined it. The paper menu was really helpful since I hate holding up lines just trying to look at and pick my choices. I didn't want anything from the Marketplace (first stop) or the others. Just wanted a sandwich and a hot dish. You can jump the line here but the set up doesn't really help with that. Narrow line, small  indoor dining space. So, I just opted to stay in line - not a big deal to me. 

I went with the Herb Roasted Chicken Sandwich and White Truffle Mac & Cheese. I received a number when I first ordered my sandwich and it actually came out to me when I was still in line. Paid and went outside to eat. Sadly didn't order any lemonade. They were out of all except 2 but I think they were making more. I'll get some next time. Maybe a macaron too - they're the size of your head!!

Price tag is a bit much but it gets you the fresh food. Just be careful or all your dishes will add up! The sandwich was great - love the fresh arugula. Mac and cheese was good too, although truffle-anything kinda tastes like metal to me. Would still get it though lol.

I'm sure lines and whatnot will be all taken care of once Lemonade is open longer! Down to try more options.
author: Shanise M.

description:
I went for the opening, which as expected was crazy (slow lines due to customers wanting to taste everything and slow service due to multiple servers at a station bumping into each other and reaching over each other), but they had several extra staff members on hand to help explain and direct people. I'm sure the craziness will die down and it'll be a good spot for grab-n-go (or dine in, especially on the patio).

The setup is mix and match sides, salads, and meats, and sandwiches, but note the menu options rotate and aren't always available (my first two choices, quinoa and butternut squash, weren't offered). Instead I had the Israeli Couscous (bland, except for a hint of parmesan), Curry Cauliflower (good curry flavor and nice crunch from the bits of almonds), and Kale & Kumquat Salad (with a kick; I like the unusual option of kumquats). While I'd eat the latter two again, they'd need to paired with a heartier side as I was hungry shortly after lunch.
 
It's a good addition to the neighborhood, but definitely more targeted toward the Land & Sea eaters (it is a whole station, after all). What would make it 4 stars for me (in order of importance):
1) Veg protein options
2) Nutritional info
3) Compostable containers
4) A low-calorie, low-sugar lemonade option (I'd rather spend my calories on food than drinks!)
author: Cristina S.

description:
Be careful at Lemonade... If you're not making your selections carefully, you could end up having an $18 lunch. I've seen it happen on many occasions! 

Overall, Lemonade is a great lunch spot that has a lot of variety (cold salads, proteins, sandwiches and hot items like braised meats and mac and cheese). The food is hearty but portions are on the smaller side, particularly to go (it seems like more food when you get it for here). I typically get two cold salads ($2.95 each) and a braised meat ($7.95) or two cold salads, a braised meat and a grain. It's not a cheap lunch but the quality is definitely worth the price.
author: Wendy L.

description: This place is pretty expensive for what you are getting, but it is a good healthy lunch and it's nice that it caters to the gluten free/vegetarian people like me. I got a kale salad, lentil/wild rice mixture, and veggie chili (that tasted and looked more like veggie soup). The portions are very small. The lemonade was great!
author: Kaitlyn N.

description:
First time at Lemonade and the people there were so nice. They explained everything to us and told us  about each portion's pricing and walked us through the ordering process. We chose a full Caesar salad, truffle mac & cheese, and a blood orange lemonade. The Caesar salad came with a slice of seasoned and toasted bread (supposed to be a crouton?) and it was tasty when dipped in the truffle mac. The truffle mac & cheese was so good, they didn't skimp on truffle at all and the cheese sauce was really creamy. The blood orange lemonade was refreshing - would definitely get again and I love their ice cubes but they put so much. 

Minus 1 star because everything is on the pricey side, esp the "land & sea" options.
author: Tammy P.

description:
When my friend and I first entered the restaurant, we were handed a menu by an employee. The line was not that bad since it was around late noon.  My friend and I both ordered the white truffle mac &cheese. It was such a struggle ordering the white truffle mac & cheese cause we didn't know that you could "cut" and walk to the sides area near the cash register. We spent 15-20 minutes waiting in line for the sides. Everyone seemed really confused as to what/how to order. They gave me a number card with my white truffle mac & cheese, which left me wondering what it was for? After ordering that, I went to the register to also order lemonade. I ordered the blood orange lemonade, and my friend ordered the original lemonade. 

The white truffle mac & cheese was very filling even though the cup they filled it in looked small. The blood orange lemonade was tart and delicious. If you're going there for their original lemonade, I'd suggest buying from Hot Dog on a Stick or Chick fil A.
author: Erica K.

description:
You walk into Lemonade and some people are waiting in line, some are just standing there and other people are walking to and fro. What is going on? 

Well for the people just standing there, they're probably figuring out what to get because you have a lot of options at the Marketplace bar where they serve signature seasonal salads. One order is about two scoops for $2.95. You are free to mix and match across the menus and also ask for samples if you want to try an item before committing. I got two Marketplace portions - the orecchiette pasta & cherry tomatoes and the arugula salad with asian pears. I also got the truffle mac and cheese which they scoop it into a tiny bowl. My total came out to be $11.65 after taxes and 3% Healthy SF tax. 

MARKETPLACE (signature seasonal salads) - $2.95 (1 portion = 2 scoops)
LAND & SEA (eg. ahi poke) - $6.95 (1 portion = 2 scoops)
MAC N CHEESE - $4.50 (1 portion = 2 scoops)
LEMONADES - $3.50

The food is yummy and it's similar to getting food from the Whole Foods bar only at a much higher quality since it's not sitting out as long. The staff is super friendly and helpful so props to them for their patience and smiles as customers try to sample everything. Subscribing to the email newsletter sent me an email for a complimentary lemonade with any $10 purchase (Offer valid through Dec 1, 2016). I got the blood orange lemonade. It was not too sour and similar to a tarty Hawaiian Punch. I wish I tried their macarons, they were huge! Almost the size of a hamburger bun. 

There is inside and outside seating. The seating is not so great near the bathrooms since you can see into the bathrooms when people go in and out and I wish it was more hidden and out of sight from the dining area.
author: Diana C.

description:
I passed this place s few time and thought it was related to lemonade as the name suggests. Instead it's a salad and sandwich bar.
A really bright cheerful place with friendly servers and a colorful array of salads and protein.  The salads are $2.95 and the proteins are $2.95 also.  I opted for fig and black kale plus BLT Panzamello for my protein, a combo of turkey, advocsdo, tomatoes.& arugula.  It was really tasty.  
Overall, I would go back to try other salads.  Kinda small portions compared other salads I've tried such as Buckhorn but definitely worth s try.
author: Elaine Y.

description: I noticed Lemonade when I saw that it was moving into the La Boulange spot in the Inner Sunset. Let me say--if you have ever met someone who loves lemonade, the drink, it was mee. So I had to find out what this was about. Started in southern California, this fast casual restaurant serves up Cali light cuisine. I think if you are a vegetarian, you will find it favorable. I was totally confused when I walked into the location near the Metreon. First, I could not find the spot..and then when I went inside, I didn't know where to start..The menu is exciting..it's overwhelming. There's so much to choose from..How do you know where to start? I decided to get a grown up grilled cheese with backyard grilled chicken salad on side. It came with kettle chips. I also got the strawberry rhubarb lemonade. It was about $16.50 for all this. It was a simple meal. I wouldn't mind coming back to try a load of other things, but I am reluctant because I think it's a little overpriced. I wish the servings were a little larger. I wasn't completely full. Lemonade is a nice fast casual experience. Although, service was a little wonky. I had to remind the guy to give me a bag of chips with the sandwich. So much to choose from, I'm sure you'll enjoy a meal here.
author: Denise C.

description:
3.5-star rating with a potential for 4 stars!

I think your experience here will really depend on what you order (does that sound too obvious?). For me, there weren't too many items that tickled my fancy just from looking or reading the description. To their credit, Lemonade allows you to sample whatever you want!

When you walk in, there's one staff member who'll ask you if you've been there before and if not, he'll give you a brochure-style menu and explain how to order. You basically order as many items as you want, and they'll add it all up! Think buffet-style but without the AYCE price :P

The restaurant is bright and there's both indoor and outdoor seating. It does get very packed during prime lunchtime, so I'd get your food to go. If you get your food to go, they scoop whatever you want into these clear containers. I feel like the portioning isn't consistent, and it looks like some people get bigger scoops than others. I also feel like to-go gets smaller portions.

Both times I went, I had their seasonal salad, which had arugula and apple slices. I don't know what dressing it was, but it's a little tart. i would definitely recommend this (:

Watermelon Radish & Seared Ahi Tuna: YUM! I loved the snap peas in this, and the sesame vinaigrette really pulled it all together. 
Seared Ahi Tuna: Meh. You get a really small portion, and the tuna itself isn't anything fantastic. BUT the orange-ginger ponzu was delicious!
Mac and Cheese: I liked this better than the White Truffle Mac, but I didn't find it to be anything special. I think it was overcooked since they just keep it all in a big pot.
White Truffle Mac and Cheese: Meh. I didn't particularly care for this, and I don't really remember if I could taste the truffle or not.
Turkey 'El Tijuana' Sandwich: This was super good, especially the jalapeno aioli. For the price, you get a pretty good sandwich too. 

I'd come back for the Watermelon Radish & Seared Ahi Tuna and their sandwiches.
author: Doris K.

description:
First time here but I've heard many friends rave about Lemonade in SoCal. I enjoyed my experience and the food! The food was really delicious, and its location is perfect. I love that I can sample what they can offer as samples before committing to that dish because I actually ended up picking something else that I didn't think I would like. I tried a handful of their marketplace dishes and really liked the watermelon pickle ahi tuna, though I wish I had some more tuna in my order. I also liked the BLT one. As for the entrees, I really liked the shrimp skewers (they give three on a stick) and the seared ahi tuna (very black peppery). 

And the lemonade! I've tried three of them seeing as there was a line behind me that was slowly building. I actually ordered the blood orange one instead of the guava that I thought I would have liked. The guava lemonade was more tarty than I like my drinks. I also really liked the blueberry mint lemonade!

-1 because I wish they gave me more food... I finished my plate and finished some of my friends'.
author: Sara T.

description:
The concept is great. 

The execution is pretty good. 

Though there are some hangups. Line is very long for pretty much no reason; they have enough cashier station to keep the line moving and yet it there's quite a wait while one or two customers have to sample the entire menu.  If they expedited the line at lunch, and breakfast rush, this would really be a next level place.

The poke is pretty legit, and they managed to turn the BLT into a "salad"... including the bread. Definitely an A for inventiveness.
author: Oleg H.

description:
Had no idea there was a Lemonade in SoMa, so when I stumbled upon this yesterday I decided to opt for a later train to give myself time to stop in. Oh wow, am I ever glad I did. 
I've been hearing about Lemonade seemingly forever, and coveting the meals of friends on Instagram for just as long, but since I didn't live super close to one I was just biding my time until my turn came around. 

Unlike most places that you crave and anticipate for a long period of time, this one totally lived up to the hype. I tried 5 (yes 5!) different menu items before landing on my selections. Everything I tasted was amazing. The poke was fresh and melt-in-your-mouth perfect. The truffle mac was out of this world. The pasta salad with kalamata olives & feta was unreal. Aaaand then if that wasn't great enough, the lemonade itself. The namesake. Good lord, 5 options?! But, I knew as soon as I saw the cucumber mint that my heart would belong to no other. So I ordered my beverage without second thought and then rushed to a table to pig out on my feast for one. 

Pros: Tons of options, clearly labeled veg/vegan selections, unlimited sampling of menu items, friendly staff, clean location, DELICIOUS FOOD!

Cons: Everything is way too enticing... I have zero self control and caved hard on a multiple day sugar / dairy fast for this. But its fine, really. No regrets. 

Cannot recommend enough.
author: Casey-Erin H.

description:
If you've never been to Lemonade, I would say that it's a very very miniature version of a food court- you pick different options and each food item has a price attached to it, so it sneakily adds up. 

I was kind of disappointed with this place because not only was the line long, but they ran out of a lot of food that I wanted (i.e. They ran out of pesto for all their sandwich options). The portions are also probably not the most filling so you'll be leaving the door with ~$10 less. Truffle Mac and cheese is probably the most decent thing I had (although the pasta was a little soft and it came out lukewarm)

To be fair, the line does go by pretty quick and they have a staff at the line to answer any questions. The Market Place (aka cold side dishes) are generally all in stock so if that's what you're looking for, but no guarantee on anything else.
author: Sammy T.

description:
Kept seeing this place, and how they always have a good crowd during lunch hours. Being really close to my office I decided to tryout this place with a group of coworkers. At first their menu/ordering can be a tad confusing to first-timers. It isn't really clear on where to begin your order, and they could work on the flow of the line a bit better. 

This place is more on the healthy side of things, and offers GF options as well as low carb/high protein. I think I paid around $15 and got a decent amount of food. Everything was well seasoned and the taste and service was great - they just need to work out a better way of ordering.

Overall this is a great place for lunch if you're looking to eat healthy.
author: Austin R.

description: The food was delicious, however I would say the prices are a little steep for what you're getting. I had to get the obligatory lemonade to try since I was visiting from Chicago so it was a must for me. The lemonade was delicious though! I'm taking a star off because of the lack of indoor seating at this location. There are only 4 booths and we didn't even go during a busy period. Sitting outside was kind of unpleasant due to the birds (which were not shy at all) coming up to tables to grab scraps! Overall I am glad to have gotten the experience to eat Lemonade and got to live up my inner youtube guru's lifestyle; I'd gladly come back if there was more seating inside!
author: Megan C.

description: Being my first time here, I was unaware of how the menu system really worked, but realized that it was relatively straightforward once I thought about it a little. The employee behind the food was really helpful in explaining things to me, giving me popular favorites and recommendations, and encouraging me to sample before I tried. The green bean/chicken salad (I'm forgetting the actual name of the salad though) is apparently a popular favorite and I liked it. I'm a fan of mashed potatoes and they do theirs well. The miso beef was also good and went well with the mashed potatoes. Decently priced. Would come again.
author: Thomas C.

description:
The food was pretty good (probably closer to a 3.5-4 ish), but the service left much to be desired, even though we went there on a slow late Sunday evening. The server was so quiet that I could barely hear him over the counter, and he was almost too shy to be in food service (?) (I asked him how to order food at Lemonade, and he gave a nervous half hearted answer?) and this happened repeatedly as I went through the cafeteria-style display of the food and had questions about dishes. When I got to the cashier, the people in front of us paid in cash, but at that time, the cash box was taken away from the register and we ended up wasting 5 minutes waiting for the cash box to come back. Once it was finally my turn to check out, the poor cashier couldn't figure out how to print a receipt since we had to sign it but the receipt printer was having issues, and we had to wait for his manager to come help him figure it out. Also, while we were waiting for that, the server came over (with his food service gloves still on!!!!) and tried to help the cashier by poking around on the register tablet. Yikes. Basically, I spent over 10 minutes waiting to check out. 

Only redeeming factors - my boyfriend accidentally spilled the lemonade that we ordered, and they immediately gave us a free one and cleaned up the spill. And the butternut squash/corn salad, miso ribs, and truffle mac and cheese were pretty yummy.
author: Jess L.

description:
My friends and I wanted to get a quick bite our trip to the SFMoMA and Yerba Buena Center for the Arts and decided to share small bites. A little confusing at first around how to navigate, but luckily they have signs to guide you along the way. I like the abilities to pick and choose different items and beware, it could easily get pricey if you compile a hearty meal.

We got the truffle mac and cheese and brussel sprouts. And I got the Blood Orange Lemonade. 

Both sides were from the hot items and I have to say, were solid pics. All of us enjoyed the creamy texture of the mac and cheese, not too thick and heavy, and the flavor of the brussel sprouts, not bitter and sweetened by the onions and other fixins in the mix.

I really enjoyed the Blood Orange Lemonade because it was not too sweet and had a good balance between the lemon and orange flavor. Very refreshing and satisfying! 

All in all, a nice light and refreshing cap to our trip to the museums and looking forward to trying out the bigger menu items in the near future.
author: Vincent L.

description:
I haven't tried the lemonade at Lemonade, so take this review as you like. But, I know one thing: the truffle white mac and cheese here is BOMB! Omg, so so so so good! Try it for your self! I also had the pineapple chicken with green beans and the tuna poke. Everything was really good and the location is clutch (near the AMC at Yerba Buena park).

I guess I'll have to come back and try the namesake of this place!!
author: Vasiliy M.

description: Fresh and what we needed in between walking around neighborhoods in SanFran in our girls weekend.  It's like a freshfresh Kneader's.  More homemade.   There are multiple flavors of lemonade and food if you needs snack or meal.   Funny that a cup of lemonade was one of the highlights of our day!
author: Alice D.

description: Decided to try it because I've heard great things and my friend wanted to go! We got poke bowls. Not sure how two poke bowls and two lemonades come out to $42.....not to mention I've had better poke =\ wasn't bad though.
author: I'manee B.

description:
So happy with all of the Lemonades opening across the Bay. This one is no exception, except that it is abnormally packed all of the time with its prime location in Yerba Buena and next to Moscone Center.

Like all of the locations, the set-up is (still) confusing and completely chaotic. If you're getting a sandwich, you're allowed to "cut" the Marketplace people, but then people in line get all confused and wonder why you're cutting. Most of the time, I just end up waiting in line regardless of the section I'm actually trying to access.

MARKETPLACE
Seasonal cold sides, vegetarian options towards the front, meat options towards the end
++ Watermelon radish ahi tuna
++ Pineapple coconut chicken
+ Shaved brussel sprouts with parmesan and dates
+ Tomato and avocado with pine nuts
- Roasted broccoli with ricotta in champagne vinaigrette 
- Baby endive and grilled chicken with persimmons, fava beans, and hazelnut vinaigrette
-- New Mexican chili roasted butternut squash

LAND AND SEA
++ Ahi tuna and avocado poke with tangerines, radish, and sesame

BRAISES AND HOT SIDES
The braises are pretty good, but really poor value at $8 each. Also, all of the braises are kind of sweet, which I'm not a huge fan of, but it's still solid.
+ Red miso short rib
+ Whiskey apple BBQ brisket
-- Lamb tagine meatballs- last time I came and got the meatballs to go, and they gave me THREE meatballs. For $8! This was super annoying, and I won't ever be getting this (or probably braises) again.
++ White truffle mac 'n cheese
+ Harissa roasted cauliflower with red onion and parmesan breadcrumbs

LEMONADES
Lemonades are also too sweet for me, and I had a pretty bad sugar crash afterwards. The flavor varieties are often interesting though. Try the unsweetened one, but they only offer that in one flavor each week. 
+ Blood orange

Except for a meal to end up around $15-20 per person.
author: Alice T.

description: Super confusing on first visit but lots of great options - many on the healthy side.  Mango chicken bowl is a good intro meal.
author: Robert M.

description: 5 stars is for the Business Manager, Fouad R. for his sincere response to rectify the 1 star that I left on my review.  True signs of a good business person.
author: Ly L.

description:
11.08.16

I was uber excited to try this place and enjoy the day's sunshine. Maybe I hyped it up too much for myself, but I was left disappointed in the food selections. The ahi tuna was not cut well and was too soggy and saucy. I could barely get through half that order. The marketplace selections were fine, but nothing to write home about. The redeeming factor was their lemonade (who would have thought?).

https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lemonade-san-francisco-3?select=Ozxx6R5m1DPtQwqgVtyaWA&userid=tGgTIueZy1JNTzQD9rkZLQ

Total damage: $18.31
author: Jenny L.

description:
3 for Food, 2 for Service

I always liked the Lemonade back home, so I was excited to visit this one a few weeks ago. Lemonade is basically an upscale cafeteria with LOTS of different nicely prepared vegetables, some sandwiches, some "sides" (mac n cheese, stews, mashed potatoes, etc), a couple desserts, and some varieties of lemonade (watermelon, mint, original, etc). I have always really liked the sandwiches at Lemonade, particularly the Herb Grilled Chicken and the Tomato& Mozzarella. When I tried these sandwiches at these restaurant, they were like they always were: very good. At this restaurant, I also had the option to order the "sandwich plate," which came with my sandwich, some kettle-cooked-type chips, and a fairly large salad. Together, these things take up a very large plate, so I was unable to finish the whole thing. The plate was about ~$12, which is a little pricey but still reasonable for how much food you get. The price of the lemonade was a little excessive ($3.50 for an unrefillable cup).

What I didn't quite like about my experience a few weeks ago was that I ordered my plate and they were prepping my sandwich when they realized that they had none of the side salad I wanted. i wouldn't have necessarily ordered a plate if I knew that the good salad was gone, but I still got the replacement salad, the Pacific Rim salad. My parents and I all thought that this salad was kind of crappy and bland. Also, the cashier rung us up for the wrong order.

Seating is pretty limited inside the restaurant, but there is also some seating outside and in the park area. It is a pretty pleasant place to sit when weather is nice.

Today, I tried to visit again, and as we were walking in the restaurant, someone stopped us and told us that they were not going to be opening on-time today. Notably, it was already 10 minutes late (11:10). As we were leaving, they locked the doors behind us, indicating (to us) that they would probably be another 10-15 minutes late. I have a short lunch and was really craving Lemonade, so I was a little disappointed.
author: Kristin A.

description:
Yummy! Lemonade has made it to the Bay :)

If your boss offers to take you out to lunch, but not a sit-down fancy lunch... come here! Lemonade has an eclectic blend of side dishes and really outstanding mains. Their mac n' cheese is pretty unparalleled and their green beans in coconut flakes are a mouthwatering side. To top off your savory blend, grab their super large sweet lemonades at the cashier.

Three stars because the wait here during lunch is simply ridiculous if you're hungry. Not sure how Lemonade can change that, maybe another location? Also because the prices are hard to swallow unless you take my advice and have the boss pay for it! ;-)
author: Kerry G.

description: The Poke was pretty good.  The Peach Ginger Lemonade tasted like regular lemonade. I couldn't taste peach or ginger at all in it.
author: Mitch M.

description:
Seriously in love with this place.

I was nearby for a convention at the Moscone center and wanted to try this place. They have so many different options for you to pick from.

They have all sorts of lemonades and I believe some get rotated. But you can also the cashier to try a sample before you buy. My favorites are the blood orange lemonade and the guava limeade.

As for the food, you have the option of eating there or getting the food to go. Each portion costs a certain amount, so depending on how many portions you get or how many different items you want to try, it'll definitely add up. I tried the pineapple chicken and green beans, so flavorful. The sesame marinated lo mein is definitely a must try. The snap peas and edamame is refreshing and has a nice crunch to them.

They have so many options to pick from and the dishes change daily. You can pick from cold dishes, or hot dishes, or made to order sandwiches. They even have desserts in a jar for you to try.

I'll definitely come back to try more of the different options.
author: Andrea G.

description:
Wow there is a Lemonade now in San Francisco!

Some people come for the different kinds of lemonade but I come for the giant macaroons.  I love macaroons and I don't know anywhere else you can get macaroons that big.

For the food, Lemonade has cafeteria style service so you can add items freely onto your plate.  Be careful of overspending here!  Everything looks so good so it is very easy to rack up a huge bill.

I love the atmosphere which captures the relaxed LA vibe from where the restaurant originates. It's sunny, healthy, sleek, innovative, and cheery.
author: Joan W.

description:
Short Story:  A very popular, very expensive place...for lunch (at least).

Long Story:  I came here around 11:45AM on a weekday for lunch.  There was already a small and growing line.  This place recently opened when I went there and I believe they were still trying to get the hang of things.  The line management was not that great.  The products are seperated into meats, soups, vegetables so you don't need to stand in one line.  However, we were not told this so we ended up standing in the wrong line for several minutes.

The prices are also a bit high for my tastes..even for it being in SF.  A small portion of pork...maybe 6oz costs about $7 or something.  Their lemonade was way too sweet.  I liked the ambiance and decor...with many windows and outdoor seating.  The service was okay...nothing to write home about but also nothing to complain too much.  

Verdict:  I might check them out when I'm back in the area...
author: Michael W.

description: Ordered poke off their site (which had no pictures) and got a single, small scoop of just the fish with nothing else. Misleading and not something I would pay $9 for again.
author: Bobby D.

description:
Balance is important in life. If my hair is too greasy I look like a wet sewer rat. Too clean and its a hopeless tangled mess. This place strikes a great balance of food quality, value and efficient service.

Fast casual dining here - good for health conscious people who care about the quality of the food they eat and need not get waited on to feel good about ones self. 

You just got off work and need dinner yet you've still got some things you need to finish up before the morning. Cafeteria style means efficiency. 

The food is the shining star and you can tell that the chef has a say in what goes on. Smoked salmon, salads - toasted-to-order sandwiches. 

Its both a seasonal menu and a menu that changes during the day. This means less variety but what they do offer is fresh as can be. I personally like smaller menus because of this. Come with an open mind. Be flexible. Not a place for a stick in the mud. :)

This is the first of many stores to come and opened recently on May 5th and it takes the place of La Boulange.
author: Stefan T.

description:
Finally we have one in SF. Been wanting them to open a Lemonade here after trying this in LA. Came on opening day.

The dishes on their menu are rotated throughout the day so you might not get what you want on the menu depending on the time that you arrive. 

I always like the marketplace selections. Got the couscous and BLT which were pretty good however after awhile they started to taste way too salty. Which I countered with the coconut apple lemonade. If you like your lemonade sweeter, you'll find their's is a bit more on the sour side. But whatever floats your boat. Also got the salmon louie which I do not think is worth $6.99 coming with a scoop of salmon louie served inside a medium sized avocado. Might stick with the marketplace selections and skip out on the land and sea and sandwiches. You can also sample whatever you want before making selections which is great!
author: Tatiana T.

description:
Horrible service.  Natalie should not speak to guests so rudely.  We were really excited to try this place and got there before close.  We were waiting patiently in line when Natalie came up to us and the others waiting in line and yelled "We're closed!  Sorry! We're closed! "Then proceeded to yell at her coworker that was helping someone that "they were closed and to not serve anyone."  I understand restaurant hours but have some tact when telling people who WOULD have spent money at your place of employment and even tipped you, and to feed one in your party and deny the rest of us and give our one lucky friend the food for free??? How about you say that you are sorry but no longer serving for the evening.   Try that next time Natalie.

Update 4/12/18 I was reached out to by the manager below and asked for my personal information for the GM to follow up on this and reluctantly I gave it up in hopes it might actually "make it right". 8 days later and still no further communication.  Starts at the top down....
author: Rebecca S.

description:
The food and lemonade approached ok but the service was confused and frustrating.

The menu lists a bunch of combinations you can make out of their pre-made salads, sandwiches and braises. I was in a hurry, so I picked a combo that let me select four portions of their cold salads, instead of waiting for them to heat up a sandwich. The salads were all fine.

I had my food about two minutes after walking into the restaurant, which was what I needed. But then I had to stand in line for another ten or so, waiting to pay and order a drink. While I was in line, I passed the braises, which I couldn't see when I ordered and probably would have gotten if I had. When I finally got to the register I was running late and paid a confused cashier who I had to remind to hand me the lemonade she'd just poured for me.

The watermelon rosemary lemonade was only ok. It tasted fine, but I couldn't tell there was any rosemary in it at all. 

There are better places to choose than this one.
author: Michael M.

description:
Really cool concept but for the price, not sure I will be a frequent visitor.  Lemonade has an assembly line of different options, similar to a school cafeteria.  You make your selections from salad to hot entrees to soups and such.  One thing I did love was the option to "build" your own meal from these options.  I didn't pay much attention to the price of each side or entree I selected.  I got the register and ordered a blood orange lemonade which everyone and their mamas talk about.  After the cashier rang me up for my order (3 meatballs, a small side salad and a small container of chicken and the drink), I was SO shocked when it came out to $28.
